questions.text: The veins accompanying branches of thoracoacromial artery drain in?
questions.solution:
• The axillary vein is joined by the venae comitantes of the brachial artery, a little above the lower border of the teres major.
  • It lies on the medial side of the axillary artery.
  • At the outer border of the first rib, it becomes the subclavian vein.
  • It receives 5 out of 6 tributaries corresponding to the branches of the axillary artery and the cephalic vein.
  • Veins accompanying branches of thoracoacromial artery drain directly into the cephalic vein.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female working in an agricultural field was attacked by a honey bee. After some time, she felt itchy all over her body, had difficulty in breathing, was unable to drink water, was nauseated, and lost her consciousness. She was admitted to the Emergency department. On examination, the skin was cold and moist, and her blood pressure was significantly reduced. Immediately, she was given an injection of Epinephrine and received oxygen inhalation before being shifted to the ICU. A blood smear was taken for diagnosis, and the smear showed the following findings. Based on the image and clinical scenario, select the correct option for cell A and B.
questions.solution:
Cell A is basophil, and cell B is a mast cell. Both basophils and mast cells are involved in allergic reactions and anaphylaxis, and they release histamine, bradykinin, serotonin, and heparin. However, basophils are found in circulation, while mast cells are located in tissues and immediately outside capillaries and nerves.

Reference: Guyton and Hall textbook of medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no. 437

questions.text: A 30 year old patient presents with fever and severe calf pain. On examination conjunctival suffusion is seen with petechial eruption. Per abdomen shows tender hepatomegaly and icterus. RFT is normal. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The presence of severe myalgia in calf muscle with fever, conjunctival suffusion and icterus is seen in leptospirosis.The KFT is currently normal as renal failure occurs in the second week. Renal manifestations of leptospirosis is hematuria.

ATN occurs during the second week due to hypovolemia and decreased renal perfusion.

questions.text: During the metabolic response to injury, the body reprioritized protein metabolism away from peripheral tissues and towards key central tissues such as the liver, immune system and wounds. One of the main reasons why the reutilisation of amino acids derived from muscle proteolysis leads to net catabolism is that the increased _________ efflux from muscle is derived, in part, from the irreversible degradation of branched chain amino acids.
questions.solution:
• Alanine and glutamine are released from muscle during proteolysis.
  • Alanine is transported to the liver and converted to glucose.
  • Glutamine is transported to the liver and other tissues, where it is used for energy or amino acid synthesis.
  • Branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) are also degraded during muscle proteolysis.
  • The increased efflux of alanine and glutamine for gluconeogenesis contributes to net catabolism of amino acids.
  • This net catabolism leads to a decrease in muscle protein and muscle mass.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 5

questions.text: Interval marked with * is known as ?
questions.solution:
Figure shows the possible outcomes for a given disease process. There is nothing to be gained in screening diseases whose onset is quite obvious. Detection programmes should be restricted to those conditions in which there is considerable time lag between disease onset and the usual time of diagnosis. In this period, there are usually a number of critical points which determine both the severity of the disease and the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. There is clearly little value in detecting disease in advance of the usual time of diagnosis unless such detection precedes the final critical point beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would be done. Detection programmes should therefore concentrate on those conditions where the time lag between the disease's onset and its final critical is Efficiently long to be suitable for population screening.

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no151

questions.solution:
Phosphatase test used to check adequacy of pasteurisation of milk

questions.text: All of the following muscles bringing abduction of arm at shoulder joint, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Deltoid: This muscle is responsible for the abduction of the arm at the shoulder joint. It is the main muscle involved in lifting the arm away from the body.

Supraspinatus: This muscle is also involved in the abduction of the arm at the shoulder joint. It works together with the deltoid to lift the arm.

Serratus Anterior: This muscle assists in protracting the scapula (shoulder blade) and is not directly involved in the abduction of the arm.

Middle Fibers of Trapezius: The trapezius muscle is responsible for multiple movements of the scapula, but its middle fibers are not the primary muscles involved in the abduction of the arm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with heat intolerance & menstrual abnormalities. On examination, a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland is present. Which of the following features will not be present in her?
questions.solution:
The patient is showing symptoms of hyperthyroidism, also known as thyrotoxicosis. Common features of hyperthyroidism include heat intolerance, menstrual abnormalities, diffusely enlarged thyroid gland (goiter), and other symptoms such as increased GI motility (leading to diarrhea), increased stroke volume (due to increased heart rate and contractility), and tremors (due to increased sympathetic activity).

However, decrease protein breakdown is not a typical feature of hyperthyroidism. In fact, hyperthyroidism is associated with increased metabolic rate and protein catabolism, leading to weight loss and muscle wasting.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no. 597

choices.text: MVP is more common in connective tissue diseases such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding prolapse (MVP) is true?
questions.solution:
• MVP is common in heritable connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers Danlos syndrome.
  • The exact cause of MVP is often unknown, but some cases have a genetic basis with reduced type III collagen production and collagen fibril fragmentation.
  • Physical examination often reveals a mid or late systolic click, followed by a high-pitched, mid-late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur, heard best at the apex.
  • Murmur radiation depends on the involved leaflet, with posterior leaflet prolapse radiating to the heart's base and anterior leaflet prolapse radiating to the axilla and back.
  • The click and murmur occur earlier with standing, Valsalva maneuver strain phase, and interventions decreasing LV volume, exaggerating mitral leaflet prolapse.
  • Conversely, squatting and isometric exercises that increase LV volume diminish MVP, with the click-murmur complex delayed or disappearing.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2000

choices.text: Reiter's disease is an autoimmune disease characterised by the triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis and polyarthritis.
Common triggers include chlamydial urethritis, less commonly gonococcal urethritis and diarrhoea secondary to Salmonella, Shigella or Campylobacter.
It is an HLA-B27 associated condition
The conjunctivitis (present in around 50%) and arthritis typically occur 1-3 months after the primary infection.

questions.text: All are true about Reiter's disease except:
questions.solution:
Reiter’s disease (synonym: sexually acquired reactive arthritis)

Reiter’s disease is an autoimmune disease characterised by the triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis and polyarthritis. Common triggers include chlamydial urethritis, less commonly gonococcal urethritis and diarrhoea secondary to Salmonella, Shigella or Campylobacter. It is an HLA-B27-associated condition. The conjunctivitis (present in around 50%) and arthritis typically occur 1–3 weeks after the primary infection. Diagnosis is made on clinical grounds and treatment is largely symptomatic, although antibiotic treatment of the precipitating infection is important.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1554

questions.text: The interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host is known as
questions.solution:
Generation time is defined as “the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host”. In general, generation time is roughly equal to the incubation period. However, these two terms are not the same. The time of maximum communicability may precede or follow the incubation period. For example, in mumps, communicability appears to reach its height about 48 hours before the onset of swelling of the salivary glands. With person-to-person transmission of infection, the interval between cases is determined by the generation time. Further difference is that the term “incubation period” can only be applied to infections that result in manifest disease, where as “generation time” refers to transmissions of infection, whether clinical or subclinical.

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 108

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is involved in meralgia paresthetica?
questions.solution:
The lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh (L2, L3)

    • It is a branch of the lumbar plexus. It emerges behind the lateral end of the inguinal ligament, divides into anterior and posterior branches.
    • It supplies the skin on the anterolateral side of the thigh and on the anterior part of the gluteal region.
    • Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh may get entangled in the inguinal ligament.
    • This leads to pain on lateral side of thigh.
    • It is called ‘meralgia paraesthetica’

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume – 2, 8th edition, page no – 47, 55

questions.text: A 23-Year-old Male accidentally falls from the balcony of the 1st floor on his left shoulder. Apart from superficial bruises, no deep injuries are found. He complains of pain on the abduction of the left arm. On sensory examination with a cotton wisp, it was found that sensation was lost over the upper lateral part of the left arm. Which of the following nerve is involved?
questions.solution:
In the given case, the symptoms point towards an injury of the axillary nerve (C5-C6), which is responsible for:

  • Motor: Deltoid muscle - abduction of the shoulder (15 to 90°)
  • Sensory: Upper and lateral part of the arm (Regimental badge area).

Therefore, in cases of shoulder dislocation with an axillary nerve injury, the limb's attitude will be abduction and external rotation. To assess axillary nerve involvement, one needs to look for paresthesia over the regimental badge area.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no. 752

questions.text: All of the following medications used in the acute management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction are appropriately matched to its mechanism of effect except
questions.solution:
All of these choices are appropriate therapy for patients with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) in certain situations. Aspirin is an irreversible cyclooxygenase inhibitor and thus inhibits the production of thromboxaneA2. Beta blockers reduce myocardial oxygen demand by reducing cardiac chronotropy and inotropy. They should be used with caution in patients with MI and any signs of delayed conduction (prolonged PR interval), heart failure, or risk for cardiogenic shock.

Clopidogrel inhibits the P2Y12 adenosine diphosphate platelet receptor to inhibit platelet aggregation. Abciximab and eptifibatide are glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors that also inhibit platelet aggregation.

While nitroglycerin is effective for anti-anginal effects in the setting of STEMI, it enacts those effects through decreasing preload and perhaps through some direct nitric oxide–induced coronary vasodilation.

Nitroglycerin has minimal effect on systemic afterload.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2061

questions.text: The oesophagus is a muscular tube connecting the pharynx to the stomach. It starts at the level of the cricoid cartilage at______ and ends at the oesophagogastric junction (OGJ) opposite __________
questions.solution:
The oesophagus is a muscular tube connecting the pharynx to the stomach. It starts at the level of the cricoid cartilage (C6 vertebra) and ends at the oesophagogastric junction (OGJ) (opposite T11 thoracic vertebra).

questions.text: Microfilaria in mosquito is which type of biological transmission?
questions.solution:
The infectious agent undergoing replication or development or both, in vector and requires an incubation period before vector can transmit Biological transmission is of three types :

  • Propagative : The agent merely multiplies in vector, but no change in form e.g., plague bacilli in rat fleas,
  • Cyclo-propagative : The agent changes in form and number, e.g., malaria parasites in mosquito,
  • Cyclo-developmental : The disease agent undergoes only development but no multiplication e.g., microfilaria in mosquito.
  • When the infectious agent is transmitted vertically from the infected female to her progeny in the vector it is known as transovarial transmission.
  • Transmission of the agent from one stage of the life cycle to another, example nymph to adult is known as transactional

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 106

questions.text: Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Lumpy jaw is caused by Actinomyces. They are considered as transitional form between bacteria and fungi.

Actinomyces are gram positive non motile non capsulated non acid fast. And non sporing filaments that break up into bacillary and coccoid elements.

Two most important species are A israelli and A bovis. Most cases are due to A isaelli.

Young males (10-30 yrs) are most commonly affected.

Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection. It is characterised by the development of indurated swelling, suppuration and discharge of sulphur granules.

Following types of actinomycosis are there.

1. Oro- cervicofacial

This is the most common type and most commonly involved site is angle of jaw causing lumpy jaw

2. Other – abdominal, thoracic, pelvic ( associated with IUCD) , CNS musculoskeletal, actinomycetoma and disseminated.

questions.solution:

questions.text: An adult male patient presented to the OPD with spasm of muscles and increased contraction and tone with more involvement of the proximal muscles of lower extremities, waddling gait, and difficulty in the movements of the arms. On lab reports, it was found that serum Ca2+ levels are raised than normal. As a curious intern working in the OPD, you want to reach a provisional diagnosis. What is the presented condition of the patient?
questions.solution:
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a condition where muscle weakness is caused by an autoimmune attack against one of the voltage-gated Ca2+ channels in the nerve endings at the neuromuscular junction. This leads to a decrease in the normal Ca2+ influx responsible for acetylcholine release. Interestingly, repetitive stimulation of the motor nerve in LEMS facilitates the accumulation of Ca2+ in the nerve terminal and increases acetylcholine release, leading to an increase in muscle strength. This is in contrast to myasthenia gravis, where symptoms are exacerbated by repetitive stimulation.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, page no 99-120

questions.text: Glycosaminoglycans present in the basement membrane of the kidney and regulate filtration of glomerular?
questions.solution:
Heparan sulphate is associated with the plasma membrane of cells, with their core proteins actually spanning that membrane. In this, they may act as receptors and may also participate in the mediation of cell growth and cell communication. The attachment of cells to their substratum in culture is mediated at least in part by heparan sulfate.This proteoglycan is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney along with type IV collagen and laminin, where it plays a major role in determining the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th edition, page no 637,638

questions.text: In Hemochromatosis the degree of increase in total body iron stores can be assessed by:
questions.solution:
In Hemochromatosis The degree of increase in total body iron stores can be assessed by-

(1) measurement of serum iron and the percent saturation of transferrin (or the unsaturated iron-binding capacity),

(2) measurement of serum ferritin concentration,

(3) liver biopsy with measurement of the iron concentration and calculation of the hepatic iron index

(4) MRI of the liver.

In addition, a retrospective assessment of body-iron storage is also provided by performing weekly phlebotomy and calculating the amount of iron removed before iron stores are exhausted (1 mL blood = ~0.5 mg iron).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 3233.

questions.text: The most common histological subtype of bladder cancer is:
questions.solution:
• The most common histological subtype of bladder cancer is Transitional Cell Carcinoma (TCC).
  • TCC arises from the transitional epithelium lining the bladder and is the most prevalent type of bladder cancer.
  • It accounts for approximately 90-95% of all bladder cancer cases.
  • TCC based on its growth pattern can be further classified into :
    • Non-invasive : Confined to the innermost lining of the bladder without invading the deeper layers or muscle.
    • Invasive: TCC infiltrates into the deeper layers of the bladder, including the muscular wall, and has a higher chance of metastasis.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1516

questions.text: All of the following are common causes of urethritis in men EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Common causes of urethral discomfort and discharge in men include Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Mycoplasma genitalium, Ureaplasma urealyticum, Trichomonas vaginalis, herpes simplex virus, and (rarely) adenovirus.

Gardnerella is the usual cause of bacterial vaginosis in women and is not a pathogen in men.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no. 1080,1236

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of UNICEF GOBI-FFF strategy?
questions.solution:
Female education is part of GOBI-FFF, not Free education.

GOBI is a strategy consisting of (and an acronym for) four low-cost, high impact, knowledge mediated measures introduced as key to having child mortality by James P. Grant at UNICEF in 1983. The measures are:

  • Growth monitoring: the monitoring of how much infants grow within a period, with the goal to understand needs for better early nutrition.
  • Oral rehydration therapy: to combat dehydration associated with diarrhea.
  • Breastfeeding
  • Immunization

Three additional measures were introduced to the strategy later (though food supplementation had been used by UNICEF since its inception in 1946), leading to the acronym GOBI-FFF.

  • Family planning(birth spacing)
  • Female education
  • Food supplementation: for example, iron and folic acid fortification/ supplementation to prevent deficiencies in pregnant women.

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 1016

questions.text: A 35 year old female presents to OPD with complaints of difficulty in walking since 3 months. She is unmarried and has multiple sexual partner. On Examination she had unsteady gait, vibration and proprioception are decreased in both lower limbs. DTR absent. What is most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points to a clinical diagnosis of tertiary syphilis, which is managed with Aqueous crystalline penicillin G (18–24 mU/d IV, given as 3–4 mU q4h or continuous infusion) for 10–14 days or Aqueous procaine penicillin G (2.4 mU/d IM) plus oral probenecid (500 mg qid), both for 10–14 days.

choices.text: Pain of 'small bowel colic' comes in waves and disappears completely in minutes when the peristaltic wave ceases
Pain of biliary colic is insidious in onset, reaches the peak in half an hour or so and ease off completely between spasms
Pain of ureteric colic is intense, lasting 1-2 minutes

questions.text: All are true about the colicky abdominal pain except:
questions.solution:
Small bowel colic is characterized by intermittent waves of pain that come and go with peristaltic contractions. When the peristaltic wave ceases, the pain disappears completely in minutes.

Biliary colic is a type of pain caused by gallbladder contraction, which is typically slow in onset, reaches its peak in about half an hour, and then eases off completely between spasms.

Ureteric colic is a severe and intense pain that occurs when a kidney stone obstructs the ureter. The pain is often described as intense and may last 1-2 minutes or longer.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1054.

questions.text: Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds ______ level
questions.solution:
• Water softening process: Reduces hardness by removing calcium and magnesium ions.
  • Hardness measurement: Typically in mg/L or ppm of calcium carbonate (CaCO3).
  • Recommended softening level: Set based on acceptable limits for household and industrial use.
  • Optimal softening threshold:150 mg per liter.
  • Purpose: Softening makes water suitable for various applications.
  • Consequence of exceeding threshold: Scale buildup, soap scum, dry skin, and irritation.
  • Softening methods: Ion exchange, lime softening, reverse osmosis.

Drinking water should be moderately hard. Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/l (150 mg per litre).

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 821

questions.text: Which of the following is the choice of antibiotic in bedridden patient in ICU with CAUTI and VAP in India ?
questions.solution:
In bedridden pt in ICU cause of catheter associated UTI and VAP are usually the multidrug resistant gram negative bacilli. Therefore empirically Beta lactam/Beta lactamase inhibitors such as Piperacillin-tazobactam or cefoperazone-sulbactam can be started which can be tailored later based on culture and sensitivity report.

questions.text: The portal vein is formed by the union of:
questions.solution:
Portal vein:

  • It is a large vein which collects blood from following organs and conveys it to the liver.
    • The abdominal part of the alimentary tract
    • The gallbladder
    • The pancreas & the spleen
  • In the liver the portal vein breaks up into sinusoids which are drained by the hepatic veins to the inferior vena cava.
  • It is called the portal vein because its main tributary, the superior mesenteric vein, begins in one set of capillaries (in the gut) and the portal vein ends in another set of capillaries in the liver.
  • The portal vein is about 8 cm long. It is formed by the union of the superior mesenteric and splenic veins behind the neck of the pancreas at the level of second lumbar vertebra. Inferior mesenteric vein drains into splenic vein.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume – 2, 8th edition, page no – 330

questions.text: Match the following types of neurons with their respective examples.
questions.solution:

Bipolar neurons: Two processes arise from the cell body. An example is the bipolar cell of the retina.

Multipolar neurons: Many processes arise from the soma. An example is a spinal motor neuron.

questions.text: The physiologically and pharmacologically active compounds of the eicosanoids is:
questions.solution:
Eicosanoids, physiologically and pharmacologically active compounds known as prostaglandins (PG), thromboxanes (TX), leukotrienes (LT), and lipoxins (LX) .

Physiologically, they are considered to act as local hormones functioning through G-protein-linked receptors to elicit their biochemical effects.

choices.text: First phase occurs due to hypoglycemia secondary to insulin release
Second phase occurs due to rapid emptying of hyperosmolar gastric content into small intestine
Diet modification is the cornerstone for treatment for dumping syndrome

questions.text: A 48 year old male patient has recurrent duodenal ulcers. For that he is operated for Billroth surgery and vagotomy. After that he develops dumping syndrome What is true statement regarding dumping syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Dumping syndrome occurs after vagotomy and drainage procedures, especially Billroth procedures.
  • It has two phases: early (15-30 min after meals) and late (90 min to 3 h after meals).
  • Early dumping symptoms : abdominal discomfort, nausea, diarrhea, tachycardia, palpitations, and light-headedness due to rapid emptying of hyperosmolar gastric contents into the small intestine.
  • Late dumping symptoms : light-headedness, diaphoresis, palpitations, and syncope, resulting from hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin release.
  • Triggered by high-carbohydrate, high-osmolarity meals, and large fluid intake.
  • Up to 50% of patients may experience it after surgery, but symptoms often improve with time.
  • Treatment involves dietary changes: small, frequent meals without simple carbohydrates and avoiding liquids during meals.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2452.

questions.text: Blaivas- Olsson classification is used for:
questions.solution:
• The Blaivas-Olsson classification system categorizes stress urinary incontinence (SUI) into four grades :
    • Grade 1: Leakage occurs with increased intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, laughing).
    • Grade 2: Leakage happens with moderate intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., running, jumping).
    • Grade 3: Leakage occurs with minimal intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., standing up from a sitting position).
    • Grade 4: Continuous leakage.
  • Treatment response prediction using this classification is as follows:
    • Grade 1 or 2 SUI patients are likely to respond to conservative treatment like pelvic floor exercises.
    • Grade 3 or 4 SUI patients are more likely to require surgery.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1498

questions.text: Number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates is known as:
questions.solution:
Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

General Fertility Rate (GFR)

It is the “number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age-group (15-44 or 49 years) in a given year”.

Total fertility rate represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women now in each age group. It is computed by summing the age-specific fertility rates for all ages; if 5-year age groups are used, the sum of the rates is multiplied by 5. This measure gives the approximate magnitude of “completed family size”.

Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR)

Average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span (15-44 or 49 years), assuming no mortality.

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 570

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertrophy of prostate and was admitted in the hospital for 3 weeks. Subsequently developed suspected cather associated urinary tract infectin. The tip of catheter was sent for culture and was grown on blood agar. After 24 hrs the blood agar shows the following appearance. What is the likely causative agent for UTI ?
questions.solution:
The figure is swarming growth. It is given by Proteus mirabilis.

Proteus mirabilis is gram negative facultative anaerobe with swarming motility and an ability to self elongate and secrete a polysaccharide which allows it to attach and move along surfaces like catheters, intravenous lines, and other medical equipement. It can cause infections related to long catheterization, improper catheter cleaning or care, and underlying illness, especially when forming biofilms on these surfaces. Proper infection control measures are crucial to manage and prevent infections caused by this pathogen in healthcare settings.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 289

questions.text: Match correctly the types of conduction shown in the figure and the protein helpful in such conduction, respectively.
questions.solution:
Transmission from synaptic junctions or receptors along axons to their termination is called orthodromic conduction. Conduction in the opposite direction is called antidromic conduction.

Kinesin proteins are involved in transporting cellular cargo, including synaptic vesicles, along axons towards the axon terminal (orthodromic direction). Dynein proteins are responsible for the transport of cargo in the opposite direction, away from the axon terminal (antidromic direction).

Reference: Guyton and Hall textbook of medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no. 94

choices.text: Purines are adenine and guanine and pyrimidines are uracil and cytosine
Watson and Crick discovered structure in 1973

questions.text: DNA is a genetic material. True about DNA structure:
questions.solution:
Structure of DNA

Elucidated by Watson and Crick based on the X-ray diffraction picture taken by Rosalind Franklin in 1953 and got Nobel prize in 1962.

Salient Features of Watson–Crick Model of DNA Right-handed Double stranded DNA helix.

Purines are Adenine and Guanine and Pyrimidines are Cytosine and Thymine.

Based on Pairing Rule:

Adenine always pairs with Thymine.

Guanine pairs with Cytosine Two strands are antiparallel.

The polarity of DNA is such that:

One strand runs in 5’ to 3’ direction. Other strand runs in 3’ to 5’ direction.

Adenine pair with Thymine by 2 Hydrogen bonds. (A = T)

Guanine pair with Cytosine by 3 Hydrogen bonds (G = C)

Grooves of the DNA

There are two types:

  • Major groove
  • Minor groove

Grooves act as sites of DNA-Protein interaction needed for regulation of gene expression.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th edition, page no 359-362.

choices.text: Upper airway surgery such as uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is as effective as oral appliances.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a BMI of 32 Kg/m2 has recently been diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea with an apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) of 13 per hour. He does not have a history of snoring. He presents to the clinic for follow-up because he has tried wearing (CPAP) at home but has not felt comfortable with it. He asks if there are other potential treatment options for his sleep apnea. Which of the following would be a possible alternative therapy?
questions.solution:
• Patient tried CPAP therapy but found it uncomfortable.
  • Possible alternative therapy: An oral appliance (mandibular advancement device).
  • Oral appliances reposition the jaw and tongue during sleep to keep the airway open, reducing the severity of sleep apnea.
  • Suitable for patients with mild OSA (AHI <15).

Other options:

  • Bariatric surgery: Effective in patients with morbid obesity and severe disease.
  • Supplementary oxygen: Effective in decreasing central apneas, but not obstructive apneas.
  • Upper airway surgery: Not as effective as oral appliances and is most commonly used in patients with significant snoring

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2209

questions.text: Polymazia may be associated with all other congenital diseases except:
questions.solution:
Polymazia

Accessory breasts have been recorded in the axilla (the most frequent site), groin, buttock and thigh. They have been known to fluctuate in response to hormones in a physiological manner, such as pubertal enlargement and lactation. They may also show the same spectrum of pathological diseases observed in normal breasts. Polymazia may be associated with other congenital diseases, such as vertebral anomalies, cardiac arrhythmias or renal anomalies.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 926

questions.text: Which of the following is not the content of WHO SAFE strategy for Trachoma prevention?
questions.solution:
Elimination programmes in endemic countries are being implemented using the WHO-recommended SAFE strategy. This consists of:

Surgery to treat the blinding stage (trachomatous trichiasis);

Antibiotics to clear infection, particularly mass drug administration of the antibiotic azithromycin, which is donated by the manufacturer to elimination programmes, through the International Trachoma Initiative;

Facial cleanliness; and

Environmental improvement, particularly improving access to water and sanitation.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 73.

questions.text: One bottle of blood is transfused to the patient. How much amount of Hb (Hemoglobin) content will increase in the patient's blood per 100 ml?
questions.solution:
The average Hb content in the blood is 15 gm/dl. This means that in 100 ml of blood, there will be 15 gm of Hb. One bottle of blood contains 350 ml of blood, so the total amount of Hb in one bottle will be 52.5 gm (15 gm/dl * 350 ml).

When this 52.5 gm of Hb is transfused to 5 liters (5000 ml) of the patient's blood:

5000 ml = 52.5 gm

100 ml = ?

Using a simple proportion, we find that the amount of Hb in 100 ml of the patient's blood will be 1.05 gm. Rounding off, the answer is 1 gm/dl.

Reference: Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page no: 623

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient had complaints of Generalised weakness and Jaundice, anorexia for 3 months. She was diagnosed as Hepatitis B. All of the drugs are used to treat chronic Hepatitis B except?
questions.solution:
Zidovudine (AZT) is not used to treat chronic Hepatitis B; it is an antiviral drug primarily used to treat HIV/AIDS.

Entecavir, Telbivudine, and Lamivudine are all antiviral medications used to treat chronic Hepatitis B. These drugs work by inhibiting viral replication and reducing the viral load in the body, helping to improve liver function and symptoms associated with Hepatitis B.

In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms of generalized weakness, jaundice, and anorexia are indicative of chronic Hepatitis B, and appropriate treatment with antiviral medications would be necessary to manage the condition.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2595.

questions.text: All of the following are increased in the integrated response to surgical injury except:
questions.solution:
In the integrated response to surgical injury, ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone), adrenaline (Epinephrine), and cortisol are typically increased.

  • ACTH : Stimulates cortisol release from the adrenal glands, increasing cortisol levels.
  • Adrenaline: stress hormone released from the adrenal glands, increases heart rate, BP, and providing a burst of energy.
  • Cortisol: regulates metabolism, inflammation, and immune function during the stress response.
  • Testosterone: Not typically increased in the surgical stress response.

Testosterone is a male sex hormone and is not directly involved in the acute stress response following surgical procedures

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 4

questions.text: Protocol used to facilitate appropriate communication between health care workers is:
questions.solution:
The SBAR (Situation-Background-Assessment-Recommendation) technique provides a framework for communication between members of the health care team about a patient's condition.

S = Situation (a concise statement of the problem)

B = Background (pertinent and brief information related to the situation)

A = Assessment (analysis and considerations of options — what you found/think)

R = Recommendation (action requested/recommended — what you want)

SBAR is an easy-to-remember, concrete mechanism useful for framing any conversation, especially critical ones, requiring a clinician’s immediate attention and action.

SPIKES protocol is used to inform bad news to patient or relatives.

GATHER protocol is used to counsel the patient.

There is no protocol named as Medicom.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no. 934, 935

The activation of apo-transketolase (the enzyme protein) in erythrocyte lysate by thiamin diphosphate added in vitro has become the accepted index of thiamin nutritional status.

questions.text: A 20 year old male patient presents with features of acute renal failure 5 days after an episode of diarrhea. Blood investigation shows thrombocytopenia and Hb-10g/dl. Peripheral smear shows Schistocyte. What is likely the cause?
questions.solution:
Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is characterized by the triad of :

  1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA):
    • The presence of fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes) on peripheral blood smear.
    • Decreased Hemoglobin levels (anemia) due to the destruction of RBCs.
  2. Thrombocytopenia (Low platelet count in the blood) :
    • Can lead to bleeding tendencies and purpura (small, pinpoint-sized red or purple spots on the skin).
  3. Acute kidney injury :
    • Sudden decline in kidney function (increased serum creatinine levels).
    • Decreased urine output.
    • Presence of proteinuria (excess protein in the urine).

Most cases affect children <5 years old with bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain.

Neurological symptoms may develop, especially in adults, such as dysphasia, hyperreflexia, and encephalopathy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2364

choices.text: Elective caesarean with delayed consecutive adrenalectomy 6 week later

questions.text: A 25 yr old pregnant female patient in the third trimester of pregnancy presented with hypertensive emergency and diagnosed as a case of pheochromocytoma after further work up. What is the further management of this patient ?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma in pregnancy. PCC in pregnancy may be silent and present as a hypertensive emergency or it may mimic an amniotic infection syndrome or pre-eclampsia. Without adequate α-blockade, mother and unborn child are threatened by a hypertensive crisis during delivery. In the first and second trimesters the mother should be scheduled for laparoscopic adrenalectomy after adequate α-blockade; the risk of a miscarriage during surgery is high. In the third trimester, elective caesarean with delayed consecutive adrenalectomy 6 weeks later should be performed. The maternal mortality rate is 50% when a PCC remains undiagnosed.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 902

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding post exposure prophylaxis of Rabies?
questions.solution:
If immunoglobulin was not administered when vaccination was begun, it can be administered up to the seventh day after the administration of the first dose of vaccine. Beyond the seventh day, Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) is not indicated since an antibody response to anti rabies vaccine is presumed to have occurred. Immunoglobulin should never be administered in the same syringe or at the same anatomical site as vaccine.

All other statements are correct.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a known case of hypertension presents to the ED complaining of intermittent chest palpitations lasting for a week. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, and vomiting.His blood pressure (BP) is 130/75 mm Hg, heart rate (HR) is 130 beats per minute. An ECG is seen below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a rhythm disturbance of the atria that results in irregular, chaotic, ventricular waveforms. This chaotic activity can lead to reduced cardiac output from a loss of coordinated atrial contractions and a rapid ventricular rate, both of which may limit diastolic filling and stroke volume of the ventricles. Atrial fibrillation may be chronic or paroxysmal, lasting minutes to days. On the ECG, fibrillatory waves are seen and accompanied by an irregular QRS pattern. The main ED treatment for atrial fibrillation is rate control. This can be accomplished by many agents, but the agent most commonly used is diltiazem, a CCB with excellent AV nodal blocking effects.

  1. If the patient was unstable, he should be immediately cardioverted. However, this patient is stable and asymptomatic; therefore, the goal in the ED is rate control.
  2. Catheterization would be correct if the patient exhibited ST-segment elevations on the ECG.
  3. Amiodarone is also used for rate control in atrial fibrillation; however, it is not a first-line agent and is recommended to be used selectively in patients with a low left ventricular ejection fraction.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1905

questions.text: Triad of 'cholelithiasis, diarrhoea, neurofibromatosis' is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Somatostatinomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that produce somatostatin, inhibiting insulin, glucagon, and gastrin release.
  • The classic triad of cholelithiasis, diarrhea, and neurofibromatosis is associated with somatostatinoma.
    • Cholelithiasis: Gallstone formation due to reduced liver bile production from somatostatin's effects.
    • Diarrhea: Caused by inhibited gastrin release, leading to decreased stomach acid and nutrient absorption.
    • Neurofibromatosis: A disorder causing nervous system tumor growth, often seen in somatostatinoma patients.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 905

questions.text: Which of the following is the Best Protein Quality Assessment Index?
questions.solution:
FAO recommended replacing the PDCAAS with the new scoring system termed the digestible IAA score (DIAAS). In DIAAS, the constituent indispensible amino acids (IAA) of a protein source are corrected for its true ileal digestibility and the lowest scoring AA is termed as limiting and this defines it's the DIAAS score. Therefore, there is a need to determine true ileal IAA digestibility of habitually consumed foods and mixed diets, preferably in humans;

DIAAS = True ileal digestibility of limiting amino acid x Limiting AAS

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 724

questions.text: A patient with Giant cell arteritis presents with a history of headache, Jaw claudication and polymyalgia rheumatica. What will be the first line of treatment?
questions.solution:
• Objective of treatment in Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA): Prevent visual loss, manage large vessel inflammation, and reduce symptoms.
  • Glucocorticoid therapy (prednisone 40-60 mg/d) is highly effective and responsive in treating GCA symptoms.
  • Initial treatment with high-dose prednisone, followed by a gradual tapering over time.
  • Methylprednisolone (1000 mg daily for 3 days) considered for ocular signs to protect remaining vision.
  • Tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) is an FDA-approved option, effective in GCA.
  • Tocilizumab dose: 162 mg subcutaneously once a week or once every other week with glucocorticoid tapering.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2812

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman begins hemodialysis for endstage renal disease associated with diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is her most likely eventual cause of death?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of mortality in end-stage renal disease (ESRD): Cardiovascular disease (stroke and myocardial infarction).
  • Risk factors with the general population: Diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia.
  • Specific risks in ESRD patients: Inflammation, hyperhomocysteinemia, anemia, altered vascular function.
  • Inefficient dialysis or poor adherence to therapy increases risk.
  • Hemodialysis patients are at risk of neurologic, hematologic, and infectious complications.
  • Biggest risk to survival: Cardiovascular disease, same as the general population.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page 2315

questions.text: Indications for carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients are all except
questions.solution:
• Carotid endarterectomy is a surgical procedure to remove plaque from the carotid artery. The carotid artery is a major artery that supplies blood to the brain. Plaque buildup in the carotid artery can cause a narrowing of the artery, which can lead to a stroke.

The indications for carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients:

50% or greater carotid stenosis and:

  • Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness
  • Contralateral facial paralysis or paraesthesia
  • Arm/leg paralysis or paraesthesia
  • Hemianopia
  • Dysphasia (if dominant hemisphere)
  • Sensory or visual inattention/neglect

The biochemical hallmarks of the Type I a GSD (von Gierke’s) disease are hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

In most cases, acute infection in the neonate is clinically asymptomatic, but the child is very likely to remain chronically infected.

questions.text: In SDS-PAGE, proteins are separated on basis of:
questions.solution:
• Protein Purity Is Assessed by Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis (PAGE), in the presence of the anionic detergent sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS).
  • Electrophoresis separates charged biomolecules based on their migration rates in an electric field.
  • SDS-PAGE involves polymerizing acrylamide to form a porous matrix, and SDS binds to proteins, denaturing them.
  • The addition of 2-mercaptoethanol or dithiothreitol breaks disulfide bonds, allowing separation of multimeric proteins.
  • Proteins are separated based on their molecular weight and charge, with SDS equalizing the negative charge for size-based separation.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th edition, page no 28

questions.text: All are part of 'Triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus' except
questions.solution:
Normal pressure hydrocephalus is an important cause of dementia since it is readily reversible. It may be idiopathic or develop in the context of previous brain insults, including subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH), head injury, meningitis and tumour. The CSF pressure at lumbar puncture is typically normal, but it is believed that reduced brain compliance in this condition results in transient spikes of ICP that contribute to clinical deterioration. Patients typically present with the triad of gait disturbance, incontinence and cognitive decline. Ventriculomegaly is evident on imaging, but this can also be the result of cortical atrophy due to other dementia pathologies. Diagnosis typically depends on lumbar infusion and/or drainage studies to demonstrate altered compliance and/or clinical improvement associated with CSF drainage. Treatment is typically by insertion of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 704

questions.text: Which of the following interventions have been effective in improving symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Effective intervention for chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS): Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and graded exercise therapy (GET).
  • CBT helps change unhealthy thought patterns and behaviors, educating patients, setting goals, and gradually increasing physical activity.
  • GET targets deconditioning and exercise intolerance with a home exercise program.
  • CBT and GET improve fatigue by changing perception and reducing symptom focus.
  • CBT tends to yield better improvement rates than GET.
  • Not all patients benefit from CBT or GET; predictors of poor outcome include medical and psychiatric comorbidities, disability claims, and severe pain.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 3534

choices.text: Detect the presence of Coliform organisms in a sample of water
Detect the presence of Faecal streptococci in a sample of water
Detect the presence of Cl. perfringens in a sample of water
Do the colony count of bacteria

questions.text: MPN Multiple Tube Method is done to:
questions.solution:
Multiple tube method : This test is based on estimating the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms in 100 ml of water. The test is carried out by inoculating measured quantities of the sample water (0.1, 1.0, 10, 50 ml) into tubes of McConkey's Lactose Bile Salt Broth with bromcresol purple as an indicator. The tubes are incubated for 48 hours. From the number of tubes showing acid and gas, an estimate of the MPN of coliform organisms in 100 ml of the sample water can be obtained from statistical tables. This result is known as 'presumptive coliform count', the presumption being each tube showing fermentation, contains coliform organisms. The reaction may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organisms or combination of organisms.

Other test for coliforms is Membrane filtration technique.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 820

questions.text: All are disposed by incineration /deep burial except
questions.solution:
Incineration and deep burial ( yellow bag) is recommended for anatomical waste ( human and animal), microbiological waste (Non plastic, non reusable), solid waste (Non plastic) and cytotoxic drug (Black bag)

Autoclave (Red beg) is recommended for Microbiological waste (Plastic, or reusable) and solid waste (Plastic).

Reference: Apurva Shashtri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition,page no 618

choices.text: Over 90% of patients with melena are bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz
Melena can result from bleeding in the small bowel or right colon, especially in older patients with slow colonic transit
Marked coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia is usually treated before endoscopy

questions.text: A 56 year old patient with chronic alcoholic liver disease for 10 years this time present with the Upper G.I Bleeding.He also complained about melena. What is the true statement regarding this patient?
questions.solution:
• Melena (black stools) is usually from bleeding above the ligament of Treitz (over 90% cases).
  • The ligament of Treitz marks the boundary between the upper and lower gastrointestinal (GI) tract.
  • Hematochezia (bright red blood in stools) is often from colon bleeding (~85% cases).
  • Melena can occur in the small bowel or right colon, especially in older patients with slow colonic transit.
  • Massive hematochezia may come from upper GI bleeding with rapid intestinal transit.
  • Early upper endoscopy should be considered for massive hematochezia to check for upper GI bleeding.
  • Endoscopy should be performed after resuscitation with fluids and transfusions, addressing coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia.
  • Tracheal intubation may be considered before upper endoscopy in patients with recent repeated hematemesis, particularly those with suspected variceal hemorrhage.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2403

questions.text: Inferior parathyroid gland develops from_________ pouch.
questions.solution:
The parathyroid glands develop from the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. The thymus also develops from the third pouch. As it descends, the thymus takes the associated parathyroid gland with it, which explains why the inferior parathyroid, which arises from the third pharyngeal pouch, normally lies inferior to the superior gland.

Reference : Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 850

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Management Method based on behavioral sciences?
questions.solution:
• Work sampling is a technique used to measure the amount of time that employees spend on different tasks. It is not a management method based on behavioral sciences.
  • Communication: Exchange of information between people, essential in management.
  • Management by Objectives (MBO): Sets and tracks employee goals.
  • Personnel management: Process of managing people in the workplace .It includes managing employees, including hiring, firing, training, and development.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 967/968.

questions.text: A patient presented with painful blisters on the trunk involving a dermatome as shown in the image. What is the most likely organism implicated in causing it?
questions.solution:
This is case of shingles. Caused by varicella zoster virus. It occurs in old age, 60 years and above. As a consequence of reactivation of latent infection from the dorsal root ganglion.

Dermatomes from T3 to L3 and trigeminal nerve ( Especially ophthalmic branch) are involved.

Zoster ophthalmicus- due to reactivation of ophthalmic branch of trigeminal (Gasserian) ganglia

Ramsay hunt syndrome - Due to reactivation in geniculate ganglion of facial nerve.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 478

questions.text: A 58 year old male patient has Diabetic kidney disease since 5 years.His hemoglobin was 7.9g/dl.What is the best treatment for anemia in Patient with renal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
The availability of recombinant human ESA has been one of the most significant advances in the care of renal patients since the introduction of dialysis and renal transplantation.

Its routine use has obviated the need for regular blood transfusions in severely anemic CKD patients, thus dramatically reducing the incidence of transfusion-associated infections and iron overload.

Adequate bone marrow iron stores should be available before treatment with ESA is initiated. Iron supplementation is usually essential to ensure an optimal response to ESA in patients with CKD because the demand for iron by the marrow frequently exceeds the amount of iron that is immediately available for erythropoiesis (measured by percent transferrin saturation), as well as the amount in iron stores (measured by serum ferritin).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2317

questions.text: Which type of inguinal hernia repair is seen below ?
questions.solution:
• Lichtenstein's repair is a minimally invasive inguinal hernia repair that uses a mesh patch to reinforce the weakened abdominal wall.
  • The procedure is performed under local anesthesia, and the patient typically goes home the same day.
  • The mesh patch is inserted through a small incision in the groin, and it is secured in place with staples or sutures.

Other options:

Bassini's repair: Sutures the inguinal floor for hernia repair.

Shouldice repair: Uses multiple suture layers for hernia repair.

Desarda repair: Uses a single suture layer without mesh for hernia repair.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1069

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity involves:
questions.solution:
• Cell-mediated (Type IV) hypersensitivity is initiated by activated T-lymphocytes.
  • It includes two main types:
  1. Delayed type hypersensitivity - mediated by CD-4 T cells.
  • Delayed hypersensitivity is crucial for defense against intracellular pathogens like mycobacteria and fungi.
  • Pathophysiology involves granuloma formation, characterized by activated macrophages surrounded by lymphocytes and giant cells.
  • Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) present antigens to naive CD-4 T cells, leading to the differentiation of T4-1 cells.
  • T4-1 cells secrete cytokines important for the expression of delayed hypersensitivity.
  1. T-cell mediated cytotoxicity - mediated by CD8-T cells.
  • For T-cell mediated cytotoxicity, CD8 T cells are activated by APCs presenting antigens from virus-infected cells or tumor cells.
  • Activated CD8 T cells release perforin and granzymes, causing apoptosis of the target cells (virus-infected or tumor cells).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 168

choices.text: >3 g per 24-hour proteinuria without hematuria
Macroscopic hematuria and 24-hour urinary albumin of 227 mg
Microscopic hematuria with leukocytes and 24-hour urinary albumin of 227mg

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is diagnosed with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is likely to be found in his urine?
questions.solution:
Microscopic hematuria with leukocytes and 24-hour urinary albumin of 227mg

The hallmark of glomerular renal disease is microscopic hematuria and proteinuria.

IgA nephropathy and sickle cell disease are the exception to this, when gross hematuria may be present.

Proteinuria may be heavy (>3 g per 24 hours) or lighter with microalbuminuria (30-300 mg per 24 hours) depending on the underlying disease or site of the immune lesion.

Patients with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis often have pyuria, but cultures are not expected to be positive because the infection is usually a skin or mucosal infection, and it is the immune reaction that drives the renal lesion.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2337

questions.text: Fracture of atlas is known as:
questions.solution:
• Fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra) is known as a Jefferson fracture.
  • The atlas is the first cervical vertebra that supports the skull and allows for head movement.
  • A Jefferson fracture occurs due to compression forces applied to the ring-like structure of the atlas.

Other options:

  • Hangman's fracture affects C2 due to hyperextension and distraction.
  • Chance fracture involves all three spinal columns due to flexion-distraction.
  • Burst fracture is when the vertebra explodes due to axial loading.

Atlas fracture (Jefferson fracture)

Fracture of the C1 ring is associated with axial loading of the cervical spine and may be stable or unstable. Associated transverse ligament rupture may occur. Most are treated nonoperatively in a cervical collar or halo brace.

questions.text: Ectopic ACTH secretion is most commonly seen with?
questions.solution:
Ectopic ACTH Production is predominantly caused by occult carcinoid tumours,most frequently in the lung,but also in thymus or pancreas.

Advanced small cell lung cancer can cause ectopic ACTH production.In rare cases,ectopic ACTH production has been found to originate from medullary carcinoma of thyroid or pheochromocytoma.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 599

choices.text: Breath hydrogen small bowel transit tests (lactulose or lactose 13C-ureide)
Wireless motility capsule small bowel transit study
Antroduodenal manometry (ideally prolonged [24 hours] ambulatory study)

questions.text: All tests are used for the transit function of the small intestine except:
questions.solution:
• Antroduodenal manometry: Measures small intestine pressure changes, helpful in diagnosing motility disorders like gastroparesis and small bowel dysmotility.
  • It assesses motor function and contractility in the upper GI tract (stomach and duodenum) rather than the transit function of the small intestine.

Other options:

  • Small bowel barium contrast study: Uses X-rays to visualize the small intestine, used for diagnosing structural issues like strictures and diverticula.
  • Breath hydrogen small bowel transit tests: Measures small intestine transit time, useful in diagnosing small bowel bacterial overgrowth.
  • Wireless motility capsule small bowel transit study: Involves a swallowed capsule to track food movement in the small intestine, used for diagnosing small bowel transit disorders.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1290

questions.text: National Nutrition Week is celebrated on
questions.solution:
National Nutrition Week is celebrated in the first week of September.

  • The theme for National Nutrition Week 2023 is "Eat Right, Stay Healthy". The goal is to raise awareness about the importance of nutrition.

Other options:

Option A: First week of august is celebrated as "World Breastfeeding Week".

Option C: Last week of august is celebrated as "National Organ Donation Day".

Option D: Last week of September is celebrated as "World Heart Day".

Reference: Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page no 706, 734

questions.text: Drug resistance is a big challenge in today's world. We have seen drug resistance in Salmonella, shigella and many other bacteria. We have seen ESBL producing organisms. We have seen MRSA ( Methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus). Drug of choice for MRSA is?
questions.solution:
MRSA is Methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus. In this all penicillin and other cephalosporins will not work. Vancomycin is the drug of choice for MRSA. Other drug which can be used are Daptomycin,linezolid, sulfamethoxazole with trimethoprim, Tedizolid.

Incorrect Option A: This drug is not used for MRSA

Incorrect Option C: This drug is not used for MRSA

Incorrect Option D:This drug is not used for MRSA

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 19th Edition, Page no 961

questions.text: A 58 year old male patient working in the cement construction for 25 years had complaints of breathlessness on exertion and fatigue with cough without expectoration.The chest x-ray of this patient is shown below.Which occupational material is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis- Frontal chest radiograph shows bilateral calcified pleural plaques consistent with asbestos-related pleural disease. Poorly defined linear and reticular abnormalities are seen in the lower lobes bilaterally.

Asbestos can cause Fibrosis (asbestosis), pleural disease, cancer, mesothelioma.

Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease

in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Because no specific therapy is available for asbestosis, supportive care is the same as that given to any patient with diffuse interstitial fibrosis of any cause.

Reference:Harrison's principle of medicine, 21st edition,Page no 2168

• Phyllodes tumor: Rare breast tumor composed of both epithelial and stromal cells,partly benign, with local aggressiveness.
  • Inflammatory carcinoma: Characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth of the breast.
  • Skin dimpling or puckering may be present.
  • The nipple may be inverted or retracted.
  • Cancer en cuirasse:Rare breast cancer spreading to chest skin, forming armor-like thickened skin.The skin may be red, warm, and tender.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 932

questions.text: Comment on flow volume curve shown below:
questions.solution:
• The flow-volume curve shows variable lower airway obstruction characterized by a decrease in expiratory flow rates, with a plateau or flattening of the curve at low lung volumes. This is due to the narrowing of the airways during expiration, which limits the amount of air that can be exhaled.

Other options:

  • Variable upper airway obstruction : Would show a decrease in inspiratory flow rates, with a plateau or flattening of the curve at high lung volumes.
  • Fixed central airway obstruction: Would show a decrease in both inspiratory and expiratory flow rates, with a plateau or flattening of the curve at both high and low lung volumes.
  • Normal: Would show a smooth, symmetrical curve with no plateaus or flattening.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2135

questions.text: Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating) results from cross-innervation of the dermal sweat glands by the regenerating_________nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve.
questions.solution:
Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating) results from cross-innervation of the dermal sweat glands by the regenerating postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve. It occurs in most patients but is often not significant; patients rarely mention it unless it is excessive. Common presentations are sweating and flushing in the preauricular region during meals. Minor's starch iodine test identifies the region affected. In it iodine is painted in the preauricular region, dried and covered with starch. Salivary stimulation causes sweating, which turns the starch blue. Frey's syndrome can be reduced either by raising a thick fap with all subcutaneous fat over the parotid or by interposition of tissue, such as a sternocleidomastoid fap, temporalis fascia, allo- dermal tissue or autologous fat between the skin and the surgical bed.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 848

questions.text: A veterinary doctor had pyrexia of unknown origin. His blood culture in special laboratory media was positive for gram negative short bacilli which was oxidase positive. Which one of the following is the likely organism grown in culture ?
questions.solution:
Points in favour of Brucellosis

Veterinary doctor-occupational exposure to infected animals.

Oxidase positive gram negative short bacilli.

Brucellosis is one of the common cause of PUO.

questions.text:
Match the following :

1)Nissen 360 degrees fundoplication
2)Dor anterior fundoplication
3)Normal anatomy
4)Toupet posterior fundoplication
questions.solution:
• Nissen 360-degree fundoplication: Surgical procedure wrapping the upper stomach around the lower esophagus to prevent acid reflux.
  • Dor anterior fundoplication: Surgical procedure wrapping the upper stomach around the lower esophagus from the front.
  • Normal anatomy: The natural arrangement of the stomach and esophagus.
  • Toupet posterior fundoplication: Surgical procedure wrapping the upper stomach around the lower esophagus from the back.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1116

questions.text: A child presents with vesicles in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet as shown in the image below. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.solution:
Coxsackievirus A16 is part of group of coxsackieviruses related to enteroviruses that belong to the picornaviridaae family of non enveloped linear, positive sense single stranded RNA viruses. As well as its genum enterovirus which includes polio virus and echovirus. Coxsackie virus A16 typically is most common cause of hand, foot and mouth disease in the USA. It is very contagious. They can pass from person to person on unwashed hands and contaminated surface. They can spread thorough droplets of fluid sprayed in to the air when a person sneezes or coughs. Treatment includes staying home, getting rest and drinking plenty of fluids.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 487.

choices.text: All are the part of it

questions.text: All are the part of Kiesselbach's plexus except:
questions.solution:
• Kiesselbach's plexus (Little's area) is a region in the anterior part of the nasal septum.
  • It is a common site for nosebleeds (epistaxis) due to the anastomosis of several arteries in this area.
  • The arteries that contribute to Kiesselbach's plexus include:
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery (a branch of the ophthalmic artery).
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery (also a branch of the ophthalmic artery).
  • Sphenopalatine artery (arising from the maxillary artery).


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 764.

questions.text:
A 60 year old man is being treated for pulmonary emphysema. He is admitted with labored breathing at rest with marked use of accessory muscles.Arterial blood gas analysis reveales:
pH=7.33
PaCO2-64 mmHg
PaO2=50 mmHg
HCO3=34 mEq/L
questions.solution:
• Patient with emphysema has respiratory distress and muscle fatigue.
  • Blood gas analysis shows:
  • pH=7.33 (acidosis)
  • pCO2=64 mmHg (respiratory acidosis, N=40 mmHg)
  • HCO3=increased, indicating compensation (N=22-26 mEq)
  • Diagnosis: Compensated respiratory acidosis.
  • To determine acute vs. chronic compensation:
  • For acute: For every 10 mmHg rise in pCO2, HCO3 rises by 1mEq.
  • For chronic: For every 10 mmHg rise in pCO2, HCO3 rises by 4 mEq or more.
  • The finding is Chronic compensated respiratory acidosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 367

questions.text: The neck swelling which is present in the neonate and brilliantly transilluminant____
questions.solution:
Cystic hygromas usually present in the neonate or in early infancy, and occasionally may present at birth and be so large as to obstruct labour. The cysts are filled with clear lymph and lined by a single layer of epithelium with a mosaic appearance. Swelling usually occurs in the neck and may involve the face, submandibular region, tongue and floor of the mouth. The swelling may be bilateral and is soft and partially compressible, visibly increasing in size when the child coughs or cries. The characteristic that distinguishes it from all other neck swellings is that it is brilliantly transilluminant. The cheek, axilla, groin and mediastinum are other less frequent sites for a cystic hygroma.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 805

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is evaluated for weakness. She has had several weeks of difficulty brushing her teeth and combing her hair. She has also noted a rash on her face. Examination is notable for a heliotrope rash and proximal muscle weakness. Serum creatinine kinase is elevated, and she is diagnosed with dermatomyositis. After evaluation by a rheumatologist, she is found to have anti-Jo-1 antibodies. She is also likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
• Dermatomyositis, an autoimmune disorder that causes inflammation of the muscles
  • Anti-Jo-1 is the most common antisynthetase antibody, found in about 75% of patients with inflammatory myopathy.
  • Patients with anti-Jo-1 are more likely to have interstitial lung disease than patients with other antisynthetase antibodies.
  • Other features of anti-Jo-1 syndrome include Raynaud phenomenon, nonerosive arthritis, and certain histocompatibility complex molecules (DR3 and DRw52).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no 2820

questions.text: The Shamblin Classification is used to determine the surgical resectability of which tumour?
questions.solution:
Paraganglioma (carotid body tumour)

Treatment

The Shamblin classifcation is used to determine the surgical resectability of these tumours. Type I tumours are localised and do not involve more than 180° of the carotid vessels; type II tumours surround the vessel by over 180°; and type III tumours completely encase the vessels and are more challenging to resect with higher complications and a possible need for vessel reconstruction.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 810

questions.text: Vertebral level of marked structure
questions.solution:
Origin of Superior mesenteric artery:

The superior mesenteric artery arises from the front of the abdominal aorta, behind the body of the pancreas, at the evel of vertebra L1, one centimetre below the coeliac trunk




Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th edition,page no-326

questions.text: Ramesh came into the court as a witness giving his testimony about the alleged murder of Suresh by Lokesh. Ramesh said that he saw Lokesh entering the building with a knife, about an hour before the alleged crime happened. What type of evidence is Ramesh giving?
questions.solution:
Indirect or circumstantial evidence is not the direct testimony of an eye witness, but has some bearing upon the facts of the crime. These types of evidence require the court to draw logical inferences to reach a conclusion.

Option A: Documentary evidence includes all the documents produced for the inspection of court.

Option C: Direct oral evidence is the direct testimony of an eye witness. Eg : Ramesh actually sees Suresh getting stabbed by Lokesh.

Option D: Hearsay, Eg: Ramesh hearing from Haresh, that he saw Lokesh walking around with a knife.

References: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 13,14

questions.text: A patient from Bihar presented with normoanesthetic hypopigmented lesions as shown below. He has had a past history of prolonged fever in childhood . No thickened nerves were present. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• PKDL (Post kala azar dermal leishmaniasis) develops years after visceral leishmaniasis (Kala azar) with a history of prolonged fever and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Caused by species: L. infantum, L. chagasi, L. donovani.
  • Endemic areas: North-eastern regions, Bihar, Assam, West Bengal.
  • Endemic areas: North eastern area, Bihar, Assam, West bengal
  • Presentation: Ill defined hypopigmented macules start over face and spread towards trunk and extremities, which may become nodular
  • On slit skin smear: LD bodies (Leishman-Donovan bodies) seen intra-cellularly, confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Miltefosine .
  • Less likely to be leprosy as there are normal sensations and no thickened nerves.
  • Differentiated from mycosis fungoides, a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, by the distribution of lesions.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 33.50, 140.10

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not indicated in a person with the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the features of atrial fibrillation as irregularly irregular rhythm,absence of P waves

The drugs used for atrial fibrillation include:

a. Anticoagulants like warfarin, heparin etc

b. Drugs to control atrial rate:

i. Beta blockers:Propranolol, metoprolol etc.

ii. Calcium channel blockers: Diltiazem and Verapamil

iii. Digoxin

c. Drugs to control rhythm:

i Sodium channel blockers: Flecainide, Propafenone, quinidine

ii. Pottasium channel blockers: Amiodarone, ibutilide, dofetilide

Adenosine has very very short half life (less than 10 sec.). It is indicated fortreatment of PSVT only.

Reference: Harrison's Principle of Internal Medicine, 19th edition, page no 2080

questions.text: Which of the following lingual papillae does not contain taste buds?
questions.solution:
Humans have around 9 large circumvallate papillae at the junction of the anterior two-thirds and posterior third of the tongue.

  • Each circumvallate papilla contains about 250 taste buds, but there can be individual variations.
  • Foliate papillae, found along the tongue's posterior margin, number less than a dozen on each side with around 100 taste buds in adults.
  • Fungiform papillae on the anterior tongue vary in size and shape, with several hundred present in adults, but not all have taste buds.
  • Filiform papillae are numerous but lack taste buds.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition,page no 577

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice for a corneal ulcer caused by Acanthamoeba?
questions.solution:
Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare but serious infection of the cornea that is often associated with contact lens wear. The treatment of choice for Acanthamoeba keratitis is topical biguanides, such as polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) or chlorhexidine. Topical fluoroquinolones and aminoglycosides are not effective against Acanthamoeba, and topical antivirals are not appropriate for the treatment of a corneal ulcer.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, page no 232

questions.text: Highest transmission of hepatitis B from mother to fetus occurs, if the mother is infected during:
questions.solution:
Viral hepatitis is the commonest cause of jaundice in pregnancy in the tropics.

  • Highest transmission of hepatitis B from mother to fetus occurs during the IIIrd trimester.
  • HBV is transmitted through parenteral route, sexual contact, vertical transmission, and breast milk.
  • Risk is highest (90%) if mother is positive for HBsAg and HBeAg.
  • Neonatal transmission occurs around birth through maternal blood and genital secretions.
  • HBV is not teratogenic.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 16th Edition, Page no 1862

choices.text: They occur in children or young adults

questions.text: What is true about ALK positive anaplastic large cell lymphoma Tumors?
questions.solution:
Option B & C: T-cell lymphomas with ALK rearrangements tend to occur in children or young adults, frequently involve soft tissues, and carry a very good prognosis.

Option A: Both ALK+ and ALK− tumors usually express CD30, a member of the TNF receptor family.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 605

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who has taken 10 Iron tablets presents with nausea and abdominal pain. What the antidote of Iron poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Deferoxamine is a chelating agent that binds iron and is indicated for persistent gastrointestinal symptoms, if pills are visible on radiographs, if the serum iron level is greater than 500 µg/dL, or if an estimated dose greater than 60 mg/kg of elemental iron was ingested.
  • Iron poisoning is a common toxicologic emergency in pediatrics because of the availability of iron tablets and the often candy-like appearance. In the above case, the mother was likely taking iron supplementation which the child ingested.

Reference: Goodman Gilman's Pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 1313

questions.text: A 2-day-old child was brought to the OPD with swelling over scalp since birth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
