  • Caput is soft tissue oedema that would disappear in about 48 hours after birth, crosses midline.
  • Cephalohematoma can present over a long time with collection not crossing the suture lines.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 834

questions.text: Identify the neuropsychiatric intervention procedure shown in the figure below.
questions.solution:
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a neurosurgical procedure involving the placement of a medical device called a neurostimulator, which sends electrical impulses, through implanted electrodes, to specific targets in the brain (the brain nucleus) for the treatment of movement disorders, including Parkinson's disease, essential tremor, dystonia, and other conditions such as obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and epilepsy.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 1074, 1071, 1076, 1080

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents has seizure inducing ability?
questions.solution:
Etomidate, 0.15 to 0.3 mg/kg IV, has minimal effects on the duration of electrically induced seizures and thus may serve as an alternative to drugs that decrease the duration of seizures (propofol, thiopentone) in patients undergoing electroconvulsive therapy.

Propofol has been associated with myoclonic movements.

Reference: Stoeltings pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice, 5th edition, page no 169

choices.text: Useful if done for any time within the first 24 hours.
Patient should be in a supine position with head support during the procedure.
Carbolic acid poisoning is one of the absolute contraindications of lavage.
In TCA and salicylate poisoning lavage can be done up to 12-18 hours.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about gastric lavage:
questions.solution:
It is useful any time within 3 hours after ingestion of a poison. It is done using a stomach tube (Ewald's or Boa's tube). Patient should be lying on his left side or prone with head hanging over the edge of the bed, and face down supported by an assistant, so that the mouth is at a lower level than larynx, so that any fluid which may leak out through the sides of the tube will not trickle down inside the larynx and trachea.

The only absolute contraindication is corrosive poisoning (except carbolic acid), owing to the danger of perforation.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 514,515.

questions.text: Appropriate initial therapy for acute bacterial sinusitis includes
questions.solution:
The goal of initial therapy is to prevent disease progression and the possibility of serious sequelae. Appropriately selected antibiotics are the mainstay of therapy for acute sinusitis. Systemic and topical decongestants relieve nasal obstruction, re-establish ostial patency, and ventilate the sinuses. The use of decongestants in conjunction with antibiotics has been shown to be more effective than antibiotics alone.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 772

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in
questions.solution:
• Vernal keratoconjunctivitis is an allergic eye condition in boys aged 5 to 15 years.
  • It is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE and mast cells.
  • Also called spring catarrh, it presents with itching and ropy discharge.
  • Conjunctival features: Flat-topped papillae creating a cobblestone appearance, and hypertrophy of superior limbal conjunctiva leading to Horner-Tranta's spots.
  • Corneal features: Superficial punctate keratitis, shield ulcer, and pseudogerontoxon (curved white line close to the upper limbus).
  • Keratoconus may be associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis.
  • Treatment: Topical antihistaminics, steroids, and cyclosporine for acute episodes.
  • Prophylaxis: Using topical sodium cromoglycate, ketotifen, olopatadine, or bepotastine.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, page no 181

questions.text: 32 years old primipara in labour with transverse lie. Treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
Patients in labour with transverse lie can be managed by external cephalic version followed by surgical rupture of the membrane.

But it is important to note that the patient is a primigravida with age 30 years, i.e. elderly primi, so ECV is contraindicated.

This patient requires an emergency cesarean section.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, page no 397

questions.text: Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia: Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) due to antibodies on red blood cells.
  • Decreased serum haptoglobin levels: Haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells.
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels: Result of increased red blood cell destruction, causing LDH release into the bloodstream.

Other laboratory findings that can be associated with hemolysis in WAIHA:

  • Increased osmotic fragility
  • Increased urine and fecal urobilinogen
  • Hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria, methemoglobinemia, hemosiderinuria

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th edition, Page no 658

questions.text: A home delivered newborn comes to you with yellow eyes on 2nd day of life. Serum bilirubin was 16mg/dl on 28th Hour of life. A peripheral smear is shown as below. There is a history of gallstone in father. What is the most likely cause of this hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
• The peripheral smear is suggestive of spherocytes.
  • In the neonatal period, HS is a significant cause of hemolytic disease and can manifest as anemia and hyperbilirubinemia sufficiently severe to require phototherapy or exchange transfusions.
  • Bilirubin gallstone formation is a function of age; they can form as early as age 4-5 years and are present in the majority of adult patients.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 2330

questions.text: A person experiences sadness of mood, sleep disturbance, decreased interest in all pleasurable activities. For this to be called depression, the symptoms have to be present for a minimum of-
questions.solution:
To be diagnosed with depression, the symptoms have to be present for a minimum of 2 weeks. These symptoms can include:

  • Sadness of mood
  • Loss of interest in activities that were once enjoyable (anhedonia)
  • Changes in appetite
  • Changes in sleep (insomnia or hypersomnia)
  • Changes in energy levels
  • Changes in concentration
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
  • Thoughts of death or suicide

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 360

questions.text: A 32 year-old man is apprehensive of general anesthesia and prefers a regional anesthetic. Decision is made to conduct spinal anesthesia for the repair of inguinal hernia along with midazolam and opiod to allay anxiety. But suddenly he complains of chest tightness. This is attributed to the effect of
questions.solution:
Opioids like fentanyl even given as bolus doses can cause chest rigidity or tightness, respiratory depression and sedation. They should be administrated as small aliquots and be titrated to effect.

Reference: Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice, 5th edition, page no 223

questions.text: Leading questions are allowed in all of the following situations, except :
questions.solution:
A leading question is one which suggests to the witness the answer desired, or which includes a material fact, and admits of a simple "Yes" or "No" answer (S.141 I.E.A.)

It is allowed in the following cases:

  • Hostile witness: Hostile witness is one who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing part of the truth, or for giving completely false evidence (S.l91, I.P.C.).
  • Cross examination: When the witness is questioned by the lawyer for the opposite party.
  • Dying Deposition

References: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 13

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with palpable purpura over lower extremities and buttocks. There was associated joint pain and abdominal pain. What is the treatment option of this condition?
questions.solution:
The case given here is Henoch schonlein purpura.

Henoch-Schonlein purpura is an IgA-mediated immune vasculitis involving the small vessels of the joints, kidneys, gastrointestinal (GI) tract and skin. Patients typically present with gastrointestinal complaints, palpable purpura, arthralgias, and renal involvement.

Symptomatic and supportive care are the foundations of treatment for patients with Henoch-Schonlein purpura unless there is renal involvement.

Early oral prednisone treatment is useful for the management of renal, joint, and gastrointestinal manifestations. Prednisone does not prevent renal disease; however, it reduces the risk of developing a persistent, renal disease.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 399

choices.text: Childhood infections seem to hold a protective effect on the development of allergy.
The youngest sibling has the greatest risk of development of allergic sensitization.
Among Japanese school children, positive tuberculin responses predicted a lower incidence of asthma and lower serum immunoglobulin (Ig)E at age 12 years.
Prior infection with hepatitis A was associated with having in the prevalence of elevated specific IgE levels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements does not support the hygiene theory of the development of atopic diseases?
questions.solution:
• Growing evidence suggests childhood infections may protect against allergy
  • Factors in Western living, such as smaller families and increased immunization, reduce childhood infections.
  • Studies demonstrate an inverse relationship between allergic disorders and childhood infections.
  • Early infections may influence immune responses towards allergic patterns later in life.
  • Certain infections, like hepatitis A virus, have been associated with decreased specific IgE levels.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 709

questions.text: Most common cause of visual disturbance in pterygium is
questions.solution:
• Pterygium is a degeneration of the conjunctiva caused by UV ray exposure.
  • It grows onto the cornea and has three parts: Head, neck, and body.
  • Stocker's line, a pigmented line, is near the head of the pterygium.
  • Symptoms include visual disturbance, astigmatism (usually with the rule), tear film issues, and cosmetic concerns.
  • Treatment options include leaving it if asymptomatic or excision.
  • Simple excision has a high recurrence rate.
  • Methods like Mitomycin C application, conjunctival autograft, or amniotic membrane graft may prevent recurrence.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, page no 198

questions.text: At what gestational age should the pregnancy with cholestasis be terminated.
questions.solution:
• Pregnancy with cholestasis should be terminated at 38 weeks of gestation (Option C).
  • Intrahepatic cholestasis causes troublesome pruritus due to bile acid in the blood.
  • Pruritus can be managed temporarily with antihistamines and topical emollients.
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid (10-15 mg/kg/d in 2 divided doses) relieves pruritus and improves biochemical abnormalities.
  • Fetal surveillance is important in cholestasis, with biweekly non-stress tests (NST) for perinatal monitoring.
  • Delivery is recommended at 37-38 weeks to reduce perinatal mortality.
  • In cases with jaundice (serum bilirubin >1.8 mg%), termination of pregnancy is advised at 36 weeks.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th Edition, Page no 1085

questions.text: A 70-yr old man visits OPD with history of lower back pain. X-ray shows compression fracture of spine. Her serum protein level is raised, with normal albumin levels. The findings of serum protein electrophoresis are as shown in the image. Which amyloid is likely to be deposited in the kidneys of this patient?
questions.solution:
Polyclonal IgG in normal serum (arrow) appears as a broad band; in contrast, serum from a patient with multiple myeloma contains a single sharp protein band (arrowhead) in this region of the electrophoretogram.

Certain light chains (particularly those of the λ6 and λ3 families) are prone to cause amyloidosis of the AL type, which can exacerbate renal dysfunction and deposit in other tissues as well.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 609

questions.text: A young drug addict patient presented with agitation and ulceration on skin. The patient had severe itching and scratch marks on the body. On examination there is presence of tachycardia, mydriasis and hypertension. Likely substance responsible for these symptoms is?
questions.solution:
Cocaine produces prominent CNS stimulation with marked effect on mood and behaviour. It induces a sense of wellbeing, delays fatigue and increases power of endurance. In susceptible individuals it produces a state referred to as ‘high’ leading to strong psychological but little physical dependence. Cocaine is unique among drugs of abuse in not producing significant tolerance on repeated use; sometimes reverse tolerance is seen (behavioural effects are experienced at lower doses).

Cocaine also stimulates vagal centre→bradycardia; vasomotor centre→rise in BP; vomiting centre→nausea and vomiting; temperature regulating centre→pyrexia (also due to increased heat production as a result of enhanced muscular activity).

In the periphery, it blocks uptake of NA and Adr into adrenergic nerve endings, resulting in higher concentration of the transmitter around the receptors→ sympathomimetic effect, potentiation of directly acting sympathomimetics and suppression of indirectly acting sympathomimetics. Local vasoconstriction, tachycardia, rise in BP and mydriasis are the manifestations of its sympathomimetic action.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 392

choices.text: Abduct mothers thigh and apply suprapubic pressure
Flex mothers thigh against her abdomen
Push infants head back into the uterus and do cesarean section

questions.text: A 28-year-old G1P0 woman at 39 weeks gestation presents to the labor and delivery suite and progresses through the stages of labor normally. During delivery of the infant, the head initially progresses beyond the perineum and then retracts. Gentle traction does not facilitate delivery of the infant. Which of these options is the first step in the management?
questions.solution:
The patient has shoulder dystocia and shows the Turtle sign (head initially progressing beyond the perineum and then retracting).

1st line of management: Stop fundal pressure, use McRoberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of thigh) for pubic pressure.

2nd line: Consider Woods Corkscrew maneuver.

3rd line: Cleidotomy (breaking the baby's clavicle), symphiosotomy (dividing the mother's pubic symphysis), or Zavanelli maneuver (pushing the head back and performing a cesarean section).

Fundal pressure should never be applied in shoulder dystocia cases.

For McRoberts maneuver, first flex the patient's thighs against her abdomen, then abduct them.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 469, 470

questions.text: At a constant temperature, the volume of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to the absolute pressure. This law is called:
questions.solution:
Boyle’s law: At a constant temperature, the volume of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to the absolute pressure. V ∝ 1/P

Option b: Charles' law: At a constant pressure, the volume of a fixed mass of gas is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. V∝T

Option c: Gay-Lussac's law: At a constant volume, the absolute pressure of a fixed mass of gas is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. P∝T

Option d: Dalton's law: The pressure exerted by a fixed mass of gas in a mixture of gases is the same as the pressure it would exert alone.

Reference: Costanzo's physiology, 6th edition, Page no 209

questions.text: A 9-month old child was brought in PHC for routine Measles vaccine. As a part of national guideline, Vitamin A supplement was given. What is the dose given at his age?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A is an essential nutrient for good vision, growth, and development. It is also important for the immune system.
  • Vitamin A deficiency can lead to blindness, growth retardation, and increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Dose of Vitamin A:
    • < 1 year- 1 lac IU
    • >1 year- 2 lac IU
  • The dose of vitamin A is given as a single oral dose. Vitamin A supplementation should not be given to children who are already taking vitamin A supplements.

Reference: Nutrition and child development, KE Elizabeth, 5th edition, page no 113

questions.text: 48 yrs old female dignosed with ovarian tumor. The most common complication of an ovarian tumor is:
questions.solution:
Complications of Ovarian tumour

(Mnemonics -TRIP):

  • T - Torsion: Most common complication, occurs in 12% of cases, often seen in benign tumors like dermoid cysts.
  • R - Rupture: Can be traumatic or spontaneous.
  • I - Infection: Rare complication, observed following acute salpingitis or during the puerperium as part of an ascending genital tract infection.
  • P - Pseudomyxoma peritonei:
  • Peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated mucinous material,commonly seen in mucinous cystadenoma and mucinous carcinoma of the ovaries.
  • Also seen in: -; Mucocoele of appendix.
  • Carcinoma of large intestine.
  • Appendix cancer (most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei).

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 15th Edition, Page no 382

questions.text: A 60-yr old man presents to OPD with a history of dysphagia for 4 months. On examination, multiple lymph nodes are enlarged. Head CT shows enlargement of lymphoid tissues of Waldeyer ring. On biopsy, immunostains for CD 19, CD 20 and Bcl-6 are positive, as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. In DLBCL, there is dysregulation of BCL6, a DNA-binding zinc-finger transcriptional repressor that is required for the formation of normal germinal centers.

These mature B-cell tumors express CD19 and CD20 and show variable expression of germinal center B-cell markers such as CD10 and BCL6. Most have surface Ig. DLBCL typically presents as a rapidly enlarging mass at a nodal or extranodal site. It can arise virtually anywhere in the body. Waldeyer ring, the oropharyngeal lymphoid tissue that includes the tonsils and adenoids, is involved commonly.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 600-601

questions.text: Which of the following drug is category B (adequate studies in pregnant woman have failed to demonstrate a fetal risk)?
questions.solution: Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 288

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient came to OPD with complaints of diarrhea, dermatitis and mental retardation. It was found that he was a maize eater. Which of the following could be most probably diagnosed?
questions.solution:
• Pellagra: Systemic disease due to vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency.
  • Characterized by the 4 D's: dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and potential death if untreated.
  • Dermatitis presents over sun-exposed areas, including "Casal's necklace" (eczematous lesions over the neck).
  • Common in populations consuming maize and jowar due to an amino acid imbalance, particularly an excess of leucine, hindering tryptophan conversion to niacin.
  • Other causes: malabsorption syndromes, chronic alcoholism, metabolic derangements, and certain medications.

Other options:

  • Beriberi: Caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency.
  • Night Blindness and phrynoderma: Caused by vitamin A deficiency.
  • Kwashiorkor: A form of protein-energy malnutrition.

Reference: Illustrated Synopsis of Dermatology and Sexually Transmitted Diseases, 8th edition, Page no 102

questions.text: What does the following image shows, which is the pathway acidic agents follow in the stomach?
questions.solution:
The pathway of acids and alkalis in a food-filled stomach starts along the lesser curvature of the stomach and leads to the pylorus, which explains the location of greatest damage in the food-filled stomach.

Stomachs without food tend to have significant injury in the lower half to two-thirds and may have sparing of the fundus

References: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 509

questions.text: Hypospadias in the baby was caused by maternal use of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
The drugs that have been associated with high incidence of hypospadias include:

  • Valproic acid
  • Phenytoin
  • Progesterone (often given to mothers as part of IVF treatment)
  • Diethylstilbestrol (prescribed up until the 1970s to prevent miscarriage)
  • Clomiphene (used to induce ovulation during IVF treatment)

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 12th edition, page no 1846

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by a gray-white, hazy appearance of the cornea with reduced corneal sensation?
questions.solution:
The drugs

Neurotrophic keratopathy is characterized by a gray-white, hazy appearance of the cornea with reduced corneal sensation. It can be caused by a variety of conditions that affect the corneal nerves, such as diabetes mellitus, herpes simplex infection, and trigeminal nerve damage. Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy and keratoconus do not typically cause a gray-white, hazy appearance of the cornea. Thygeson's superficial punctate keratitis is characterized by multiple, discrete, round opacities on the corneal surface.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, page no 241

that have been associated with high incidence of hypospadias include:

  • Valproic acid
  • Phenytoin
  • Progesterone (often given to mothers as part of IVF treatment)
  • Diethylstilbestrol (prescribed up until the 1970s to prevent miscarriage)
  • Clomiphene (used to induce ovulation during IVF treatment)

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 12th edition, page no 1846

choices.text: Schedule an amniocentesis for amniotic fluid bilirubin at 16 weeks
Schedule PUBS to determine fetal hematocrit at 20 weeks

questions.text: Two weeks later, the results of the patient's prenatal labs come back. Her blood type is A, with an anti D antibody titer of 1:4. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the same patient-blood grouping shows A negative, with an anti D antibody titer of 1:4 the most appropriate next step in the management-Since this patient is a primi patient and her antibody titre is 1:4 so we should follow it by doing a repeat titre after every 4 weeks.

If this pregnancy would not have been her first affected pregnancy, then amniocentesis i.e. option a would have been the correct response.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, page no 339, 458

choices.text: Enlargement of heart in response to pressure overload
Breast at puberty and during pregnancy
Bone marrow in response to hemolysis

questions.text: Example of organ showing hypertrophy as well as hyperplasia is?
questions.solution:
Hormonal hyperplasia is well illustrated by the proliferation of the glandular epithelium of the female breast at puberty and during pregnancy, usually accompanied by enlargement (hypertrophy) of the glandular epithelial cells.

Option A: The striated muscle cells in the heart and skeletal muscles have only a limited capacity for division, and respond to increased metabolic demands mainly by undergoing hypertrophy. The most common stimulus for hypertrophy of skeletal and cardiac muscle is increased workload.

Option C: The bulging muscles of bodybuilders engaged in 'pumping iron' result from enlargement of individual skeletal muscle fibers in response to increased demand.

Option D: In the setting of an acute bleeding or premature breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis), feedback loops involving the growth factor erythropoietin are activated, that stimulate the growth of red blood cell progenitors in bone marrow, allowing red blood cell production to increase as much as eight fold.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 57-59

questions.text: Which vitamin is deficient in breast milk?
questions.solution:
• Breast milk lacks sufficient Vitamin D.
  • Vitamin D is crucial for calcium and phosphorus absorption, vital for bone health.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding may not provide enough Vitamin D for infants.So, it is important for babies to get some sunlight exposure every day.
  • Daily sunlight exposure helps the body produce Vitamin D.

Reference: Nutrition and child development, KE elizabeth, 5th edition, page no 26

questions.text: A 16 years old girl is having delayed puberty. Most common cause of delayed puberty.
questions.solution:
Delayed puberty is said to occur when there is no breast development by the age of 14 and no menarche by the age of 16.

Causes of Delayed Puberty

  1. Constitutional delay (M/c cause of delayed puberty in boys and overall M/c cause of delayed puberty).
  2. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism: Defect is at the level of hypothalamus or pituitary. FSH level low < 10 m IU/ml
  3. Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism. Defect lies at the level of ovary. There is sexual infantilism and FSH levels are elevated (as the negative feedback on FSH by estrogen decreases). Levels of FSH > 30 m IU/ml.

Causes:

Turner syndrome (40 XO)

Pure gonadal dysgenesis 46 XX, 46 XY

Ovarian failure

  • Infections like mumps or tuberculosis of ovary
  • Iatrogenic (post-surgery/radiotherapy)
  • Sweyer syndrome
  • Primary ovarian failure

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 15th edition, Page no 107-112

questions.text: What is the most frequent site of involvement when leprosy affects the upper respiratory tract?
questions.solution:
The nose is by far the most frequently involved site. Mycobacterium leprae prefers an ambient temperature of less than 37°C.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 646

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient with past history of severe covid19 infection comes to you with breathlessness, tachypnoea, dry cough with reduced exercise capacity. On CT scan, diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis is made. Which of the following drug can be used for the treatment of this condition:
questions.solution:
Pirfenidone & Nintedanib Reduces fibroblast proliferation by reducing TGF beta. Given orally it is used for Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

Reference: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page no 685, 692, 1174, 1177, 1350

questions.text: Which of the following stains is not used for tattooing?
questions.solution:
The dyes used in tattooing are

  • Black: Indian ink, Carbon (soot) Red: Cinnabar, Vermillion (Mercuric Sulfide)
  • Green: Chromic Acid
  • Blue: Indian ink, China ink, Indigo, Cobalt, Prussian blue, Ultramarine
  • Gold/Platinum Chloride is used for corneal tattoo Jet black stain.

Osmium dye is used in electron microscopy staining.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 89

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major crieteria for chronic rhinosinusitis?
questions.solution:
• Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) : A long-term inflammation of the sinuses that lasts for an extended period, typically more than 12 weeks.
  • The sinuses are air-filled cavities in the bones of the face and skull.
  • They are lined with a thin layer of mucus that helps to keep the sinuses moist and clean.
  • Rhinosinusitis symptoms/signs requires:
  • 2 major factors or
  • 1 major + 2 minor.

Refence: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, volume 2, Page no .1440

questions.text: Corneal Thickness is best measured by
questions.solution:
Important Investigations Related to Cornea

Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness

Keratometry: To measure the corneal curvature

Corneal topography: Measures corneal curvature,shape and thickness

Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium.

Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography (AS-OCT): To assess different corneal layers

Vital stains:

Fluorescein stain: To identify epithelial defect

Rose Bengal stain: It stains the degenerated epithelial cells. It causes severe stinging, hence rarely used

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, page no 249

questions.text: A primigravida with full term pregnancy in labor for 1 day is brought to casualty after discharge of amniotic fluid. On examination she is dehydrated, slightly pale, bulse 100/min, BP120/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination reveals a fundal height of 36 weeks, cephalic presentation, foetal heart absent, mild uterine contractions present. On P/V examination, cervix is fully dilated, head is at +1 station, caput with moulding present, pelvis adequate. Dirty, infected discharge is present. What would be the best management option after initial work-up?
questions.solution:
Let's first analyse the condition of patient and then think about its management:

  • Patient is primigravida
  • On examination:
    • Dehydration is present
    • P/R is 100/min, i.e. tachycardia present.

P/A

  • Fundal height-36 weeks
  • Presentation-cephalic
  • FHS-Absent
  • Mild uterine contractions are present.

P/V

  • Cervix-fully dilated
  • Station = + 1
  • Caput present
  • Moulding present
  • Dirty infected discharge is present.

Most importantly-Pelvis is adequate.

This patient is undoubtedly a case of obstructed labour. As we all know in nulliparous females in case of obstructed labour-a state of uterine exhaustion is reached manifested as weakened uterine conditions.

  • In such cases, if oxytocin drip is given it may lead to rupture of uterus as lower segment is thinned out (i.e. option 'b' ruled out).
  • Craniotomy and other destructive procedures are not carried out in modern obstetrics (i.e., option 'd' ruled out).

Management of obstructed labor is cesarean section.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, page no 358, 360

questions.text: A 27-year old woman had missed abortion 5 months ago. She presented to OPD with complaint of bleeding per vagina for past 2 months. Her laboratory reports revealed raised hCG. Ultrasonographic examination showed bulky uterus. D & C was done, histologic image of which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image shows complete hydatidiform mole demonstrating marked villous enlargement, edema, and circumferential trophoblast proliferation.

Most women with partial or early complete mole presents with spontaneous miscarriage or undergo curettage because of ultrasound findings of abnormal villous enlargement. In cases of complete mole, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels greatly exceed those of a normal pregnancy of similar gestational age.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 1034

questions.text: A 50-year-old insulin-dependent diabetic patient presents with unilateral purulent rhinorrhea and proptosis. Physical examination shows ulceration and necrosis of the lateral nasal wall. Appropriate treatment of the most likely diagnosis includes
questions.solution:
Treatment of mucormycosis requires a prolonged course of amphotericin B, as well as aggressive surgical debridement of all nonviable tissue. Antifungal azoles are ineffective. The underlying condition must be corrected if possible.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 648

questions.text: A patient with new onset ocular myasthenia gravis should have a chest CT scan done to look for what associated condition?
questions.solution:
Thymoma may occur in up to 10% of patients with myasthenia gravis; consequently, a patient with new-onset myasthenia gravis should be evaluated for the existence of this tumor. Thymectomy would be the appropriate treatment if a mass is diagnosed. Graves' disease is seen in approximately 5% of these patients and can be diagnosed by an orbital CT scan in conjunction with a clinical examination. An apical lung tumor could be associated with Horner's syndrome; however, this patient did not present with symptoms suggestive of this syndrome. Also, there is no association between Horner's syndrome and myasthenia gravis. Sarcoidosis would most likely present with infiltrative or fibrotic pulmonary changes seen on chest x-ray, splenomegaly, and lymph node infiltration.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, Page no 816

questions.text: Which one of the following congenital malformations of the fetus can be diagnosed in first trimester by ultrasound?
questions.solution:
• Anencephaly can be detected in the first trimester (8-10 weeks) by ultrasound.
  • Microcephaly (decreased head size), is difficult to recognize by ultrasound, and a head circumference below 2 standard deviations from the mean is used as a diagnostic criteria in mid-trimester scans.
  • Holoprosencephaly, which involves a single centrally placed cerebral ventricle and may be associated with midline abnormalities of the face, can be recognized in the early mid-trimester using a vaginal probe.
  • Encephalocele, a bony defect with protrusion of brain tissue and meninges, can also be recognized in the first trimester.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 21st Edition, Page no 1120

questions.text: A 54 year old post-menopausal woman has lower abdominal pain since last 6 months. She complained of slight vaginal bleed occasionally. Pelvic examination shows left adnexal mass. An ultrasound shows 7 cm solid mass in left adnexa and normal sized uterus. D & C is done and biopsy results show endometrial hyperplasia. On excision of the mass, typical Call-Exner bodies are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis of adnexal mass?
questions.solution:
In adult women, granulosa cell tumors may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma.

Histopathology shows small, distinctive, gland-like structures filled with an acidophilic material recall immature follicles (Call-Exner bodies). When these structures are evident, the diagnosis is straightforward.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 1026

questions.text: A 67 year old patient with a history of heart disease had to undergo surgery for valvular replacement. Pre-anaesthetic checkup revealed the increased liver enzymes with mild kidney failure. Which of the following inhalational agents should be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Halothane is hepatotoxic, and fluorinated anesthetic agents can cause dose-dependent decrease in arterial BP and depression of the heart.

  • In contrast, Xenon has minimal impact on CVS function.
  • Xenon, an ideal anesthetic agent, is a scarce colorless and odorless gas with minimal respiratory irritation and good tolerance during gas induction.
  • Its low blood/gas partition coefficient (0.115) allows for rapid anesthesia induction and reversal.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 396

questions.text: A 23 years old girl came to opd with genital warts. Which is most commonly implicated in genital (vulval) warts?
questions.solution:
"Low Risk HPV types 6 and 11 cause nearly all genital warts."

Genital Warts:

  • Caused by HPV infection, mainly types 6 and 11.
  • Display various appearances from flat papules to verrucous, polyphytic lesions called "condyloma acuminata."
  • Occur in the lower reproductive tract, urethra, anus, or mouth.
  • Diagnosis is typically clinical; biopsy is needed only if neoplasia is suspected, and HPV serotyping is not routinely required.

Treatment Options:

  • Condyloma acuminata may resolve on its own.
  • Treatment aims for lesion removal and includes sharp or electrosurgical excision, cryotherapy, laser ablation, or ultrasonic surgical aspiration for large lesions.
  • Medical Management: Topical 5% imiquimod cream (immunomodulator),

Podophyllin,Trichloroacetic acid, Bichloroacetic acid or Intralesion injection of interferon.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, Page no 67, 619

questions.text: A previously healthy 22-yr old girl complains of weight loss and low-grade fever since 2 weeks. Gross appearance of the lung shown in image below is representative of her disease. Identify the disease condition.
questions.solution:
The patient has Primary pulmonary tuberculosis, of which Ghon complex is shown in the image. The gray-white parenchymal focus is under the pleura in the lower part of the upper lobe (red arrow). Hilar lymph nodes with caseation are seen on the left (blue arrow).

As sensitization develops, a 1- to 1.5-cm area of gray-white inflammation with consolidation emerges, known as the Ghon focus. In most cases, the center of this focus undergoes caseous necrosis. Tubercle bacilli, either free or within phagocytes, drain to the regional nodes, which also often caseate.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 371-372

questions.text: Which of the following is not normally found as part of the pathophysiology of chronic suppurative otitis media?
questions.solution:
All of the other four items are specifically mentioned as routinely present in individuals with chronic suppurative otitis media. Large multinucleated giant cells are classic for tuberculosis and/or the presence of foreign bodies but do not appear regularly in patients with chronic suppurative otitis media.

Reference: Otologic surgery by Breakmann, 4th edition, page no 86

questions.text: True about suspended animation -
questions.solution:
Suspended animation (Apparent death) is defined as "a state of body in which the vital functions are at such a low pitch that the body functions cannot be determined by ordinary methods of clinical examination".

Suspended animation may last for few seconds to half an hour or more. In this condition, actually, the circulation, respiration etc. do not completely stop but is being maintained in their minimum. Prompt resuscitation can revive the state. Apparent death is of two types:

  • Voluntary - Produced voluntarily. Yogis or 'sadhus' or 'sanyasi' may practice this method.
  • Involuntary person lands in apparent death spontaneously. Involuntary suspension of animation lasting from a few seconds to half an-hour or more may be found in:
    • After Anesthesia
    • In newborn Babies
    • Cholera/Cerebral concussion
    • Drowning
    • Electrocution
    • Shock, Sunstroke, Syncopal attack, Insanity, Hypothermia, poisoning, vagal inhibition etc., Narcotics

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 144

questions.text: Which of the following is not a layer of the olfactory bulb?
questions.solution:
The layers of the olfactory bulb are, from the periphery inward, the olfactory nerve cell layer, glomerular layer, external plexiform layer, mitral cell layer, internal plexiform layer, and granule cell layer. There is no interglomerular layer distinguished as such.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 562

questions.text: Which of the following parameters does not contribute to the pathogenesis of emphysema?
questions.solution:
Option A: In patients who develop emphysema, there is a relative deficiency of protective antiproteases, which in some instances has a genetic basis.

Option B: A wide variety of inflammatory mediators (including leukotriene B4, interleukin [IL]-8, TNF, and others) are increased in the affected parts of the lung.

Option C: Substances in tobacco smoke, alveolar damage, and inflammatory cells all produce oxidants, which may beget tissue damage, endothelial dysfunction, and inflammation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 680

questions.text: Classify following grade of hyphema
questions.solution:
• Hyphema: Accumulation of blood in the anterior chamber of the eye.
  • It is a common complication of blunt ocular injury, causing bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye.
  • The bleeding usually originates from the iris root or ciliary body face.
  • Blood settles inferiorly in the anterior chamber, resulting in a 'fluid level' appearance, unless the hyphaema is total and fills the entire chamber.
  • Uncontrolled high intraocular pressure (IOP) from hyphaema can lead to ischaemic optic neuropathy and corneal staining.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, Page no 900

questions.text: A woman comes with obstructed labour and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Two main principles in managing obstructed labor are:

  • "Never wait and watch"
  • "Never use oxytocin."

Obstructed labor can be due to passage or passenger issues, but the uterus contracts adequately.

Avoid using oxytocin in obstructed labor to prevent uterine rupture.

Management involves addressing dehydration with IV fluids and administering antibiotics for infection prevention.

Main step is to relieve obstruction through instrumental delivery or cesarean section.

During cesarean section, rule out uterine rupture.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 404

questions.text: Which of the following glycoproteins can inhibit multiple CDKs?
questions.solution:
One family of CDKIs - composed of three proteins called p21 (CDKN1A), p27 (CDKN1B), and p57 (CDKN1C) - broadly inhibits multiple CDKs.

Another family of CDKIs has selective effects on cyclin CDK4 and cyclin CDK6; these proteins are called p15 (CDKN2B), p16 (CDKN2A), p18 (CDKN2C), and p19 (CDKN2D).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 27

questions.text: A 42 year old chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency department with altered sensorium and seizures. He has not consumed alcohol for the last two days. On investigations, his serum ALT is 150, AST is 180 and GGT is 563 units per litre. Best drug for first line management of this patient is?
questions.solution:
Lorazepam has slow oral absorption. Being less lipid-soluble than diazepam, its rate of entry in brain is slower. The plasma t½ is shorter (10-20 hours); no active metabolite is produced, since it is directly conjugated with glucuronic acid, and is suitable for older patients.

However, it is quite sedative and capable of producing marked amnesia when injected i.v. Injection site complications are minor. Therefore, it is the only BZD recommended for i.m. use.

Lorazepam has been preferred for short lasting anxiety states, panic, OCD and tension syndromes, as well as for psychosomatic diseases and for i.v. use in status epilepticus.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 494

questions.text: A male patient presented with H/O fever and joint pain. Following intake of NSAIDS 5 days later developed hyperpigmentation over the nose. What is your Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chikungunya can lead to hyperpigmentation over the nose, called as chick sign.

This pigmentation is not related to drug.

FDE is a drug reaction. Vesicle or bulla develop over skin or mucosa which leaves hyperpigmentation. It reoccur over the same site if drug exposure occurs.

Dengue rash are erythema with typical appearance of 'islands of white in sea of red'.

Petechial rash may develop if platelets counts are low.

Melasma is not related to fever or NSAIDS intake. It is commonly seen in female.

Risk factors are photo exposure, hormonal imbalance or OC pill intake.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 25.75, 25.76 88.10

questions.text: A 70-year-old male, Ganesh presented to OPD with fever and sore throat with mouth ulcers. He had a history of myocardial infarction for that he was on antiplatelet drugs. His complete blood count shows: Hb 13 g/dL, Platelet count 100000/mm3, WBC 1000/mm3. If an antiplatelet drug is responsible for the above symptoms of the patients, which of the following is most likely the mechanism by which this drug is acting?
questions.solution:
Ticlopidine is the first thienopyridine drug that acts by blocking the P2Y12 type of purinergic receptors on the surface of platelets and inhibits ADP-induced aggregation.

Ticlopidine produced beneficial effects in TIAs, stroke prevention, UA, secondary prophylaxis of MI, and synergized with aspirin to lower the incidence of restenosis after PCI and stent thrombosis.

However, it produced serious adverse effects like neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, haemolysis, jaundice.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 678

questions.text: Marshall's triad includes all of the following except :
questions.solution:
Marshall's triad is seen with secondary blast injury due to flying debris, it includes:

  • Abrasion
  • Contusion
  • Laceration

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 239

questions.text: A 26 years old female in her later stage of pregnancy presented with greenish vaginal discharge. Clue cells were present on histopathology and whiff test was positive in vaginal discharge. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Trichomonas vaginitis. The drug of choice is metronidazole (2.0 g single dose is preferred) or Tinidazole.

Alternatively 400 mg BD-TDS may be used for 7 days.

The male partner should be treated concurrently in cases of recurrent infections.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 895

questions.text: Headaches more likely to occur in men include
questions.solution:
Most headache types occur more often in women. This is true for migraines, tension headaches, trigeminal neuralgia, and giant cell arteritis. The notable exception is cluster headaches, which afflict men more often than women.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effect is least likely to be observed due to use of digitalis in young patients:
questions.solution:
Side effects of Digoxin:

Extracardiac-

Anorexia, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain are usually reported first: are due to gastric irritation, mesenteric vasoconstriction and CTZ stimulation. Diarrhoea can also occur.

Fatigue, malaise, headache, mental confusion, restlessness, hyperapnoea, disorientation, psychosis and visual disturbances are the other complaints.

Skin rashes and gynaecomastia are rare.

Cardiac

Almost every type of arrhythmia can be produced by digoxin: pulsus bigeminus is common; others are nodal and ventricular extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia and terminally ventricular fibrillation.

Partial to complete A-V block may be the sole cardiac toxicity, or it may accompany other arrhythmias. Severe bradycardia, atrial extrasystoles, AF or AFl have also been noted. In about 2/3 patients showing toxicity, Extracardiac symptoms precede cardiac toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 560

questions.text: Sexual attraction to a doll or other figurative object is called as
questions.solution:
Sexual paraphilias are persistently indulged abnormal and unorthodox sexplay by using objects or parts of the body, or fantasies in which complete satisfaction is sought and obtained without sexual intercourse. Some examples are -

  • Agalmatophilia - Sexual attraction to a statue, doll, mannequin or other similar figurative object
  • Coprolagnia - Sexual pleasure is obtained from the thought, sight, or touching of excrement
  • Mysophilia - Sexual pleasure associated with something soiled or filthy, usually a kind of undergarment after use.
  • Klismaphilia - is a paraphilia involving enjoyment of, and sexual arousal from, enemas.
  • Necrophilia - desire for sexual intercourse with dead bodies
  • Mixoscopia - a form of voyeurism where sexual gratification is obtained by watching other people have sexual intercourse

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 403

choices.text: Termination of pregnancy and cyst removal

questions.text: A 20-year-young female presented for antenatal checkup. She was in Ist trimester and was diagnosed to have an ovarian cyst. Treatment of choice:
questions.solution:
1. Patient is presenting in the first trimester with ovarian cyst.
  2. The principle of treatment in case of ovarian tumour is to remove the tumour as soon as the diagnosis is made. But this principle should not be followed in the first trimester.
  3. Surgery in the first trimester is best avoided, as during surgery a corpus luteal cyst or ovary might be removed which will be detrimental to the pregnancy, which may end up in a miscarriage.
  4. Therefore, all such cases should be operated (ovariotomy/cystectomy) in the second trimester.
  5. Therefore, the best time of elective operation for an ovarian tumor in pregnancy is between 14 to 18 weeks, as the chances of abortion are less and access to the pedicle is easy.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, page no 310

questions.text: What is the optimal imaging technique for a posterior optic nerve glioma?
questions.solution:
MRI provides the best tissue contrast of structure in the orbital apex and intracanalicular portion of the optic nerve.

MRI effectively demonstrates the tumour and may show intracranial extension if present

  • CT in patients with associated NF1 shows a fusiform enlargement of the optic nerve with a clear-cut margin produced by the intact dural sheath. In patients without NF1 the nerve is more irregular and shows low-density areas.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th edition, Page no

questions.text: 17-year-old girl with a height of 57 inches presents with primary amenorrhea and rising FSH. The histological finding most consistent with her condition is:
questions.solution:
• A height of 58 inches corespondes to approximately 147 cms. Which is short stature for a female of 16 years. Her FSH levels are rising, i.e., estrogen production is low i.e., there is an ovarian cause for 1° amenorrhea.
  • Primary amenorrhea with short stature is seen in Turner's syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome (45 X) is the most common chromosomal abnormality causing gonadal failure, hence on histological examination their ovary would should low oocyte count.
  • After birth, these patients generally grow slowly. Hence, they present with short stature. (Height < 150 cms), primary amenorrhea and delayed secondary sexual characteristics.
  • They typically have many of the associated stigmata including lymph edema and sometimes large cystic hygromas of neck, webbed neck, coarctation of aorta, horse shoe kidneys.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 107

questions.text: A 68 year old female is having chronic gout since 3 years with creatinine clearance of <40mg/ml. Which one of the following drug is best suitable for this patient with renal impairment:
questions.solution:
• NSAIDs like naproxen have no role in treating chronic gout.
  • Uricosuric drugs (probenecid, sulfinpyrazone) are ineffective in renal insufficiency and stone formers.
  • Allopurinol is the drug of choice for most chronic gout cases.
  • Allopurinol is effective for both uric acid over-producers and under-excretors.
  • It is beneficial for severe cases with tophi or nephropathy.
  • During prolonged allopurinol therapy, tophi gradually disappear, and nephropathy improves.
  • Allopurinol can control secondary hyperuricemia caused by chemotherapy, radiation, thiazides, or other drugs, and can be used prophylactically in such situations.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 234

questions.text: Radhika, a 17 weeks pregnant lady, during her antenatal workup is suspected with having CAH. Best prenatal treatment for CAH is:
questions.solution:
• Prenatal treatment for CAH: Dexamethasone (DOC in mothers at risk for having an affected child).
  • Dexamethasone prevents fetal female genital virilization, crossing effectively into fetal circulation.
  • Treatment should begin early (4 to 5 weeks of gestation) for maximum benefit, not later than 8 weeks.
  • Latest recommendations advise early prenatal diagnosis by CVS with rapid sex determination and genotyping.
  • Treatment in only those mothers with an affected female child to avoid potential risks.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 15th edition, Page no 114

questions.text: Which of the following G-protein coupled receptors does not act through opening of potassium channels?
questions.solution:
GPCR that acts through opening of K+ channels can result in hyper-polarisation, thus leading to inhibition. So, receptor which causes stimulation cannot act through opening of K+ channels.

Muscarinic M2 receptor, Dopamine D2 receptor and serotonin 5HT1 receptor act through opening of K+ channels.

Angiotensin 1 receptor act by increasing Ca2+.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 56

questions.text: One of these complications is not seen with underlay tympanoplasty grafting:
questions.solution:
Blunting in the anterior sulcus, particularly anterosuperiorly, occurs to a minor degree in most lateral surface cases in overlay technique, but is of no consequence and results from the formation of excess fibrous tissue. Blunting is probably the most common healing problem encountered by the novice surgeon. It can interfere greatly with the hearing result if it is great enough to involve the malleus handle when the ossicular chain is intact.

Reference: Otologic surgery by Breakmann, 4th edition, page no 104

questions.text: Which amongst the following drug has adverse effect called as Pseudojaundice:
questions.solution:
Rifabutin causes an orange-tan discoloration of skin, urine, feces, saliva, tears, and contact lenses, like rifampin. Rarely, thrombocytopenia, a flu-like syndrome, hemolysis, myositis, chest pain, and hepatitis develop in patients treated with rifabutin. Unique side effects include polymyalgia, pseudojaundice, and anterior uveitis.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 1071

questions.text: Patient during workup of infertility is dignosed with obstructive azoospermia. Which of the following is true about obstructive azoospermia:
questions.solution:
• In obstructive azoospermia, the testicles produce sperm normally, but they are blocked from reaching the semen due to a physical obstruction in the reproductive tract.
  • The obstruction can occur at any level, such as the epididymis, vas deferens, or ejaculatory duct.
  • In this condition, FSH and LH levels remain normal, as the testicles still produce sperm.
  • It is important to differentiate obstructive azoospermia from non-obstructive azoospermia, where the testicles do not produce sperm adequately, leading to elevated FSH levels.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 13th edition, Page no 203

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly matched pair with respect to vasopressin receptor localization?
questions.solution:
There are at least three kinds of vasopressin receptors:

V1A (also called V1), V1B (known as V3), and V2.

  • V1 receptors are involved in causing vasoconstriction
  • V2 receptors are present in distal nephron and decrease the urine outflow.
  • The V1B receptors (also called V3 receptors) appear to be unique to the anterior pituitary, where they mediate increased ACTH secretion from the corticotropes.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 640

choices.text: Both mother and baby are safe
Give antiviral treatment to mother before delivery
Baby will develop neonatal varicella syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady acquires chickenpox 3 days prior to delivery. She delivers by normal vaginal route which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Varicella infection in pregnancy:

  • If varicella infection occurs during the first half of pregnancy (13 to 20 weeks), it may result in congenital varicella syndrome in the fetus.
  • Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by various fetal abnormalities and may be an indication for medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Neonatal varicella can occur if the baby is exposed to varicella just before or during delivery.
  • Varicella Ig should be given to all neonates born to mothers with clinical evidence of varicella within 5 days before delivery and up to 2 days after delivery.
  • Antiviral treatment (acyclovir) is given to neonates only if they develop neonatal varicella syndrome.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th Edition, Page no 1211, 1212

questions.text: Patients suffering from ulcerative colitis present with ulcer on anterior legs as shown in the image. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) presents as a rapidly enlarging, very painful ulcer. It is one of a group of autoinflammatory disorders known as neutrophilic dermatoses. The condition is not an infection (pyoderma), nor does it cause gangrene. It frequently is associated with an internal disease or condition. Its known associations include: Inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease) and rheumatoid arthritis. The lesion of pyoderma gangrenosum has a violaceous rim around ulcer. It heals with cribriform scar.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page nos 49.1, 49.5

questions.text: A patient was started on an anticoagulant therapy for Deep vein thrombosis. Next day he presented the features shown in the below figure. The implicated drug is:
questions.solution:
Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is a rare complication characterized by the appearance of skin lesions 3-10 days after treatment is initiated.

The lesions typically are on the extremities, but adipose tissue, the penis, and the female breast also may be involved. Skin necrosis occurs in patients with protein C or S deficiency or in those with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 594

questions.text: 36 year old female, during the workup of infertility is dignosed with luteal phase defect. What is the cause for luteal phase defect?
questions.solution:
Luteal Phase Defect:

During normal luteal phase when their is adequate progesterone secretion by the corpus luteum, adequate development of secretory endometrium occurs for blastocyst implantation. Luteal phase defect refers to a condition when production of progesterone is suboptimal by corpus luteum.

Inadequate progesterone secretion could be due to:

  • Inadequate follicular development
  • Inadequate FSH or LH secretion
  • Hyperprolactinemia

It is an inevitable phenomenon in all ART cycles.

LPD may cause implantation failure and is thought to account for 4% of infertility.

Diagnosis of LPD is not based on uniform criteria:

  • Low levels of midluteal serum progesterone (<10 ng/mL)
  • Endometrial histology done on 25th-27th day of cycle shows endometrium >2 day out of phase
  • A shortened luteal phase <14 days, are considered for the diagnosis.

Management - Micronized Progesterone

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 494, 499

questions.text: Crocodile tears are seen in
questions.solution:
Crocodile tears are seen in abnormal regeneration of 7th nerve.

It is one of the complications following facial nerve palsy. It is characterized by unilateral lacrimation with mastication and is due to faulty regeneration of parasympathetic fibers which now supply lacrimal glands instead of salivary glands.

Reference: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery, 8th Edition, Page no 103

questions.text: Which of the following drug is associated with serious consequences of Osmotic demyelination syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most dangerous adverse effect of V2 receptor antagonists is due to their pharmacological action to increase free water excretion. This may correct hyponatremia too rapidly, resulting in serious and even fatal consequences (osmotic demyelination syndrome).

Indeed, tolvaptan is labelled with a black-box warning against too rapid correction of hyponatremia and with the recommendation to initiate therapy in a hospital setting capable of close monitoring of serum Na

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 468

questions.text: A 2 month old male patient presented with yellowish skin lesion over face and scalp. What would be most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Infantile seborrheic dermatitis: Presents with yellowish greasy scales on the scalp, known as cradle cap in infants. Can also involve the face and trunk.
  • Ichthyoses: Skin disorders with scaling and redness, ranging from mild to severe, with or without systemic abnormalities. Can be genodermatoses, with a history of collodion membrane at birth and possible family history.
  • Atopic dermatitis: Appears as red, inflamed patches of skin that may be dry, scaly, and intensely itchy. In some cases, these patches can develop into small raised bumps or blisters that may ooze or crust over.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Volume I, Page no 40.1, 26.14, 41.16, 32.38

questions.text: Savita is 34 weeks pregnant presents in casualty and diagnosed as a case of APH. Vitals are unstable with BP 80/60 which of the following is next step in Management?
questions.solution:
• BP is 80/60, indicating moderate bleeding.
  • Next step in management: Blood transfusion to stabilize the patient's condition.
  • Beyond 36 weeks: Terminate pregnancy with moderate bleeding.
  • Between 32-36 weeks: Assess pulmonary maturity.
  • If maturity not achieved: Conservative management with close monitoring, blood transfusions, and betamethasone for 24 - 48 hours.
  • If the patient's condition improves with transfusion, expectant management is continued.
  • If the patient's condition does not improve, pregnancy may be terminated.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 259

choices.text: Binding to and inhibition of hair cell Na+ K+ ATPase

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism is mainly responsible for gentamicin induced ototoxicity?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides can lead to ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity and neuromuscular blockade.

  • Ototoxicity involves progressive and irreversible damage to, and eventually destruction of, the sensory cells in the cochlea and vestibular organ of the ear. The vestibular or cochlear sensory cells and hairs undergo concentration dependent destructive changes. Aminoglycoside ear drops can cause ototoxicity when instilled in patients with perforated eardrum. Such drops are contraindicated in them.
  • Nephrotoxicity consists of damage to the proximal tubules, and is reversible.
  • A rare but serious toxic reaction is paralysis caused by neuromuscular blockade. This is usually seen only if the agents are given concurrently with neuromuscular-blocking agents. It

results from inhibition of the Ca2+ uptake necessary for the exocytotic release of acetylcholine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 794

choices.text: The effect mimics that of a natural disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of an ideal homicidal poison?
questions.solution:
Ideal Homicidal Poison: The characters of an ideal homicidal poison should be:

(i) cheap,

(ii) easily available,

(iii) colourless, odourless and tasteless,

(iv) capable of being administered, either in food, drink or medicine, without producing any obvious change to prevent suspicion,

(v) highly toxic,

(vi) signs and symptoms should resemble a natural disease, or the serious ill-effects should be delayed sufficiently long for the accused to escape suspicion,

(vii) there should not be any antidote,

(viii) there should be no postmortem changes,

(ix) should not be detected by chemical tests, or other methods,

(x) must be rapidly destroyed or made undetectable in the body.

Organic compounds of fluorine (used as rodenticides), and thallium satisfy several of the above criteria. Arsenic and aconite are commonly used.

References: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 503

questions.text: A young girl on antidepressant therapy presented to the emergency with palpitations, altered sensorium and hypotension. On investigations there is a wide QRS interval and right axis deviation in ECG. Next best step in the management of this patient is:
questions.solution:
• The clinical features and ECG findings typically suggest a diagnosis of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning.
  • Antidote for TCA poisoning is sodium bicarbonate
  • Hemodialysis is not effective is TCA poisoning

Reference: Harrison's Principle of Internal Medicine, 19th edition, page no 172

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman was found to have Ca cervix, FIGO stage 2-3, locally advanced. What would be the management?
questions.solution:
As discussed, best for cervical cancer of (stages II B to IV A) is chemoradiation (i.e. chemotherapy and radiotherapy), where by cisplatin is used as a radiosensitiser to increase the sensitivity of the cells to radiotherapy before giving radiotherapy.

Since in this question -chemotherapy + radiotherapy is given as one of the options, hence, we will mark it as the correct option.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 2nd edition, Page no 787
